Addressing Polarization and Unfairness in Performative Prediction

Kun Jin
University of Michigan, Ann Arbor
kunj@umich.edu
&Tian Xie11footnotemark: 1
the Ohio State University
xie.1379@osu.edu
&Yang Liu
University of California, Santa Cruz
yangliu@ucsc.edu
&Xueru Zhang
the Ohio State University
zhang.12807@osu.edu
These authors contribute equally.
Abstract

When machine learning (ML) models are used in applications that involve humans (e.g., online recommendation, school admission, hiring, lending), the model itself may trigger changes in the distribution of targeted data it aims to predict. Performative prediction (PP) is a framework that explicitly considers such model-dependent distribution shifts when learning ML models. While significant efforts have been devoted to finding performative stable (PS) solutions in PP for system robustness, their societal implications are less explored and it is unclear whether PS solutions are aligned with social norms such as fairness. In this paper, we set out to examine the fairness property of PS solutions in performative prediction. We first show that PS solutions can incur severe polarization effects and group-wise loss disparity. Although existing fairness mechanisms commonly used in literature can help mitigate unfairness, they may fail and disrupt the stability under model-dependent distribution shifts. We thus propose novel fairness intervention mechanisms that can simultaneously achieve both stability and fairness in PP settings. Both theoretical analysis and experiments are provided to validate the proposed method.

1 Introduction

Modern supervised learning excels in many domains, especially in pattern recognition where the target data distribution is static and independent of the deployed model. However, in the presence of model-dependent distribution shifts (i.e., the model itself triggers the changes in the distribution of targeted data), most conventional training approaches will fail to find solutions that are stable and robust to such shifts. In fact, model-dependent distribution shifts are practical and commonly exist in real-world applications. Examples include strategic individuals manipulating their data (in school admission, hiring, or lending) to game the ML system into making favorable predictions [1], consumers changing their retention and participation choices (in digital platforms) based on their perception toward the ML model they are subject to [2, 3], etc.

To make predictions in the presence of model-dependent distribution shifts, Perdomo et al. [4] proposed performative prediction (PP), a framework that explicitly considers the target data distribution 𝒟⁢(𝜽)𝒟𝜽\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta})caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_θ ) as a function of the ML model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ to be optimized. While PP captures the impacts of the ML model on target data, the distribution 𝒟⁢(𝜽)𝒟𝜽\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta})caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_θ ) is solely determined by the model regardless of the original data distribution. A subsequent study [5] extended PP and proposed a more generalized state-dependent performative prediction (SDPP) framework, which considers the impacts of both model and initial data distribution. Specifically, given the deployed ML model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ and initial data distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, SDPP models the resulting target data distribution 𝒟′=T⁢(𝜽;𝒟)superscript𝒟′T𝜽𝒟\mathcal{D}^{\prime}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) using some transition mapping function T. Since PP is a special case of SDPP, we focus on SDPP in this paper.

Since the target data distribution depends on the model, the learning objective of SDPP is to minimize performative risk (PR), i.e.,

𝜽PO=argmin𝜽⁢PR⁢(𝜽)=def𝔼Z∼T⁢(𝜽;𝒟)⁢[ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)]superscript𝜽PO𝜽argminPR𝜽superscriptdefsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑍T𝜽𝒟delimited-[]ℓ𝜽𝑍\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{% argmin}}~{}\text{PR}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{% =}}\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})}[\ell(% \boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_θ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG PR ( bold_italic_θ ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z ∼ T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) ]

where ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)ℓ𝜽𝑍\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) is the loss function, Z𝑍Zitalic_Z is the data sampled from the target distribution T⁢(𝜽;𝒟)T𝜽𝒟\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) dependant on both model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ to be optimized and the initial data distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. The minimizer 𝜽POsuperscript𝜽PO\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is named as performative optimal (PO) solution. Because the target data distribution itself is a function of variable 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ to be optimized, finding the PO solution is often challenging [4, 5]. Instead, existing works have mostly focused on finding performative stable (PS) solution 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which minimizes the decoupled performative risk DPR⁢(𝜽;𝜽PS)DPR𝜽superscript𝜽PS\text{DPR}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}})DPR ( bold_italic_θ ; bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) defined as follows,

𝜽PS=argmin𝜽⁢DPR⁢(𝜽;𝜽PS)=def𝔼Z∼T⁢(𝜽PS;𝒟PS)⁢[ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)]superscript𝜽PS𝜽argminDPR𝜽superscript𝜽PSsuperscriptdefsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑍Tsuperscript𝜽PSsuperscript𝒟PSdelimited-[]ℓ𝜽𝑍\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{% argmin}}~{}\text{DPR}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}})% \stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\text{T}(\boldsymbol{% \theta}^{\text{PS}};\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}})}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_θ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG DPR ( bold_italic_θ ; bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z ∼ T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) ] (1)

where 𝒟PSsuperscript𝒟PS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the fixed point data distribution induced by 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that satisfies 𝒟PS=T⁢(𝜽PS;𝒟PS)superscript𝒟PSTsuperscript𝜽PSsuperscript𝒟PS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}};\mathcal{D}^{% \text{PS}})caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Unlike performative risk PR⁢(𝜽)PR𝜽\text{PR}(\boldsymbol{\theta})PR ( bold_italic_θ ) where data distribution T⁢(𝜽;𝒟)T𝜽𝒟\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) depends on variable 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ to be optimized, decoupled performative risk DPR⁢(𝜽;𝜽PS)DPR𝜽superscript𝜽PS\text{DPR}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}})DPR ( bold_italic_θ ; bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) decouples the two, i.e., data distribution is induced by 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT while the variable to be optimized is 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ. Although in general 𝜽PS≠𝜽POsuperscript𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PO\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}\neq\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the fixed point of Eqn. (1) and stabilizes the system: at 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, data distribution 𝒟PSsuperscript𝒟PS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also remain fixed. Many algorithms have been proposed in the literature to find 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A prime example is repeated risk minimization (RRM) [4], an iterative algorithm that finds 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (under certain conditions) by repeatedly updating the model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes risk on the fixed distribution 𝒟(t−1)superscript𝒟𝑡1\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT induced by the previous model 𝜽(t−1)superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t-1)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e.,

𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁢𝔼Z∼𝒟(t−1)⁢[ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)],𝒟(t)=T⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1)).formulae-sequencesuperscript𝜽𝑡𝜽argminsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑍superscript𝒟𝑡1delimited-[]ℓ𝜽𝑍superscript𝒟𝑡Tsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{argmin}% }~{}\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)],~{}~{}~% {}\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}).bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_θ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) ] , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (2)

However, the societal implications of PS solutions are less understood and it is unclear whether PS solutions can cause harm and violate social norms such as fairness.

In this paper, we examine the fairness properties of PS solutions 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We consider scenarios where an ML model is used to make decisions about people from multiple demographic groups, and the population data distribution changes based on the ML decisions they are subject to. We find that PS solutions can 1) incur severe polarization effects: entire population 𝒟PSsuperscript𝒟PS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is dominated by certain groups, leaving the rest marginalized and almost diminished in the sample pool; 2) be biased when deployed on 𝒟PSsuperscript𝒟PS\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and people from different groups will experience different losses. However, in many applications such as recommendation systems, school admission, and loan applications, it is critical to ensure equal quality of ML predictions and population diversity. Thus, we investigate under what conditions and by what algorithms we can simultaneously achieve stability and fairness in SDPP.

Focusing on group-wise loss disparity [6, 7] and participation disparity [2, 8] fairness measures, we first explore whether existing fairness mechanisms commonly used in supervised learning can help mitigate unfairness in SDPP settings; this includes regularization methods (adding fairness violation as a penalty term to the objective function of unconstrained optimization, e.g., [9, 10]) and re-weighting methods (adjusting weights and importance of samples in learning objective, e.g., [11, 12, 13]). We show that common choices of penalty terms (e.g., group-wise loss difference) and re-weighting designs (e.g., standard distributionally robust optimization) that are effective in traditional supervised learning may fail in SDPP settings by disrupting the stability of the system. Using repeated risk minimization (RRM) shown in Eqn. (2) as an example, this means that applying such fairness mechanisms at each round of RRM can disrupt the convergence of the algorithm and (𝜽(t),𝒟(t))superscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)},\mathcal{D}^{(t)})( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) may diverge to an unexpected state. We thus propose novel fairness mechanisms, which can be easily adopted and incorporated into iterative algorithms such as RRM. We theoretically show that the proposed mechanism can effectively improve fairness while maintaining the stability of the system.

It is worth noting that although a few recent works also studied fairness issues under model-dependent distribution shifts, they all make rather strong assumptions about the distribution shifts and do not apply to the general SDPP framework. For example, Zezulka and Genin [14], Hu and Zhang [15], Raab et al. [8] assumed there exists a causal model that depicts how data distribution would shift based on the ML model, and these causal models need to be fully known. Raab et al. [8] studied a special type of model-dependent distribution shift where only the group proportion/participation changes based on ML models. In Appendix A, we discuss these works in more detail and provide a comprehensive literature review.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 provides the background of SDPP. Section 3 formulates the problem and demonstrates the unfairness and polarization issues of PS solutions. Section 4 highlights the difficulties of simultaneously achieving fairness and stability in SDPP, where we first show that existing fairness mechanisms commonly used in supervised learning may fail in SDPP settings and then propose a novel fairness mechanism. In Section 5, we conduct the theoretical analysis and show that our method can effectively improve fairness while maintaining stability. Finally, Section 6 empirically validates the proposed method on both synthetic and real data.

2 Preliminaries: Iterative Algorithms to Find PS Solutions in SDPP

As mentioned in Section 1, the original goal of SDPP is to find the performative optimal solution 𝜽POsuperscript𝜽PO\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PO}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PO end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes the performative risk PR⁢(𝜽)=𝔼Z∼T⁢(𝜽;𝒟)⁢[ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)]PR𝜽subscript𝔼similar-to𝑍T𝜽𝒟delimited-[]ℓ𝜽𝑍\text{PR}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D})}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]PR ( bold_italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z ∼ T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) ], the loss over the population induced by the deployed model. However, solving this optimization is often challenging because the data distribution T⁢(𝜽;𝒟)T𝜽𝒟\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) depends on the variable 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ to be optimized. Thus, prior studies such as [4, 5] have mostly focused on finding performative stable solution 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the fixed point of Eqn. (1) and can be found through an iterative process of data sampling and model deployment. Specifically, denote ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟)=𝔼Z∼𝒟⁢[ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)]ℒ𝜽𝒟subscript𝔼similar-to𝑍𝒟delimited-[]ℓ𝜽𝑍\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})=\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim\mathcal{D}}[% \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) ] and let (𝜽(t),𝒟(t))superscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)},\mathcal{D}^{(t)})( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be the model parameter and data distribution at round t𝑡titalic_t of the iterative algorithm, then repeatedly updating the model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT according to Eqn. (3) could lead (𝜽(t),𝒟(t))superscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)},\mathcal{D}^{(t)})( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) converging to PS solution (𝜽PS,𝒟PS)superscript𝜽PSsuperscript𝒟PS(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}})( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) under certain conditions [4, 5].

𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁢ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1)),𝒟(t)=Tr⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1)).formulae-sequencesuperscript𝜽𝑡𝜽argminℒ𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1superscript𝒟𝑡Trsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\operatorname{argmin}% }~{}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}),~{}~{}~{}\mathcal{D}^% {(t)}=\text{Tr}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}).bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = underbold_italic_θ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = Tr ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (3)

where Tr is not necessarily the same as transition mapping T that drives evolution of data. Depending on how frequently the model is deployed compared to the change of data, Tr can be defined differently based on repeated deployment schema. Common examples include:

conventional: Tr⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1))=T⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1))Trsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡1Tsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡1\displaystyle\text{Tr}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})=\text{T}% (\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})Tr ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
𝐤𝐤\mathbf{k}bold_k-delayed: Tr(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1))=Tk(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1))=T(𝜽(t);…T(𝜽(t);T⏟k⁢ times(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1))))\displaystyle\text{Tr}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})=\text{T}% ^{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})=\underbrace{\text{T}\Big{(% }\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\dots\text{T}\big{(}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\text% {T}}_{k\text{ times}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})\big{)}% \Big{)}Tr ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = under⏟ start_ARG T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; … T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k times end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) )
delayed: Tr⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1))=T⌈r⌉+1⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟(t−1))Trsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡1superscriptT𝑟1superscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡1\displaystyle\text{Tr}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})=\text{T}% ^{\lceil r\rceil+1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})Tr ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⌈ italic_r ⌉ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

where the repeated risk minimization (RRM) [4] introduced in Section 1 corresponds to conventional deployment schema. By customizing the time interval between two deployments, we can get variants including delayed RRM and k𝑘kitalic_k-delayed RRM [5]. Note that the delayed deployment schema is a special case of k𝑘kitalic_k-delayed deployment schema, where the number of repeated deployments r𝑟ritalic_r is chosen to ensure the output distribution 𝒟(t)superscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is sufficiently close to the fixed point distribution when 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT keeps being deployed on the population 𝒟(t−1)superscript𝒟𝑡1\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Technical conditions for iterative algorithms to converge to PS solutions. As shown in [4, 5], PS solutions exist and are unique only when ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ and T satisfy certain requirements. Moreover, iterative algorithms introduced in Eqn. (3) can converge to the PS solution. We introduce them below, where ΘΘ\Thetaroman_Θ, 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}caligraphic_Z, and △⁢(𝒵)△𝒵\triangle(\mathcal{Z})△ ( caligraphic_Z ) denote the parameter space, sample space, and space of distributions over samples.

Definition 2.1 (Strong convexity of loss).

ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)ℓ𝜽𝑍\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex if and only if for all 𝜽,𝜽′∈Θ𝜽superscript𝜽′Θ\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\Thetabold_italic_θ , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ and Z∈𝒵𝑍𝒵Z\in\mathcal{Z}italic_Z ∈ caligraphic_Z, we have

ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)≥ℓ⁢(𝜽′;Z)+⟨∇𝜽ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z),𝜽−𝜽′⟩+γ2⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖22.ℓ𝜽𝑍ℓsuperscript𝜽′𝑍subscript∇𝜽ℓ𝜽𝑍𝜽superscript𝜽′𝛾2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′22\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)\geq\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime};Z)+\langle% \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z),\boldsymbol{\theta}-% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\rangle+\frac{\gamma}{2}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}.roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) ≥ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z ) + ⟨ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) , bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ + divide start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Definition 2.2 (Joint smoothness of loss).

ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)ℓ𝜽𝑍\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) is β𝛽\betaitalic_β-jointly smooth if the gradient with respect to 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ is β𝛽\betaitalic_β-Lipschitz in 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ and Z𝑍Zitalic_Z, i.e., ∀𝜽,𝜽′∈Θfor-all𝜽superscript𝜽′Θ\forall\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\Theta∀ bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ and ∀Z,Z′∈𝒵for-all𝑍superscript𝑍′𝒵\forall Z,Z^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Z}∀ italic_Z , italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_Z, we have

‖∇𝜽ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)−∇𝜽ℓ⁢(𝜽′;Z)‖2≤β⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2,‖∇𝜽ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)−∇𝜽ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z′)‖2≤β⁢‖Z−Z′‖2.formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsubscript∇𝜽ℓ𝜽𝑍subscript∇𝜽ℓsuperscript𝜽′𝑍2𝛽subscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2subscriptnormsubscript∇𝜽ℓ𝜽𝑍subscript∇𝜽ℓ𝜽superscript𝑍′2𝛽subscriptnorm𝑍superscript𝑍′2\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{% \theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime};Z)\|_{2}\leq\beta\|\boldsymbol{% \theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2},~{}~{}\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}% }\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{% \theta};Z^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq\beta\|Z-Z^{\prime}\|_{2}.∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_β ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_β ∥ italic_Z - italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
Definition 2.3 (Joint sensitivity of transition).

Let 𝒲1subscript𝒲1\mathcal{W}_{1}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the Wasserstein-1 distance measure. The transition mapping T is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-jointly sensitive if for all 𝜽,𝜽′∈Θ𝜽superscript𝜽′Θ\boldsymbol{\theta},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\Thetabold_italic_θ , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ and 𝒟,𝒟′∈△⁢(𝒵)𝒟superscript𝒟′△𝒵\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\triangle(\mathcal{Z})caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ △ ( caligraphic_Z ),

𝒲1⁢(T⁢(𝜽;𝒟),T⁢(𝜽′;𝒟))≤ϵ⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2,𝒲1⁢(T⁢(𝜽;𝒟),T⁢(𝜽;𝒟′))≤ϵ⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟′).formulae-sequencesubscript𝒲1T𝜽𝒟Tsuperscript𝜽′𝒟italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2subscript𝒲1T𝜽𝒟T𝜽superscript𝒟′italic-ϵsubscript𝒲1𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{W}_{1}(\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}),\text{T}(\boldsymbol% {\theta}^{\prime};\mathcal{D}))\leq\epsilon\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{% \theta}^{\prime}\|_{2},~{}~{}\mathcal{W}_{1}(\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D}),\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon% \mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}).caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D ) ) ≤ italic_ϵ ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ≤ italic_ϵ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .
Lemma 2.4 (The existence of a unique PS solution [4, 5]).

The SDPP problem is guaranteed to have a unique PS solution if all of the following hold: (i) Loss ℓ⁢(𝛉;Z)ℓ𝛉𝑍\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex; (ii) Loss ℓ⁢(𝛉;Z)ℓ𝛉𝑍\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) is β𝛽\betaitalic_β-joint smooth; (iii) T is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-joint sensitive and ϵ⁢(1+β/γ)<1italic-ϵ1𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\beta/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + italic_β / italic_γ ) < 1. Moreover, if any of these conditions is violated, the iterative algorithms may fail to converge to the PS solution.

3 Unfairness and Polarization in SDPP

Problem Formulation.

In this work, we study SDPP with different demographic groups, where an ML model 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ is trained to make predictions about individuals from multiple groups distinguished by a sensitive attribute s∈𝒮𝑠𝒮s\in\mathcal{S}italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S (e.g., gender, age, race), whose data distribution changes based on the deployed ML model and such model-dependent distribution shift can be captured by transition mapping T. Suppose individuals from group s𝑠sitalic_s follow the identical data distribution 𝒟s(t)superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at the round t𝑡titalic_t of an iterative algorithm, and let ps(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the size of group s𝑠sitalic_s as the fraction of entire population at t𝑡titalic_t. Then the data distribution of the entire population is 𝒟(t)=∑s∈𝒮ps(t)⁢𝒟s(t)superscript𝒟𝑡subscript𝑠𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}p_{s}^{(t)}\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with ∑s∈𝒮ps(t)=1subscript𝑠𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡1\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}p_{s}^{(t)}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1.

Note that the above SDPP with multiple groups is a general framework. By specifying the transition mapping T, many problems studied in prior works can be regarded as a special case. This includes:

  1. 1.

    Strategic classification with multiple groups [16, 17]: individuals in applications such as lending, hiring, and admission may manipulate their data based on ML model strategically to increase their chances of receiving favorable decisions, leading to changes in group distribution 𝒟s(t)superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Decision-making systems under user retention dynamics [2, 12, 18]: ML models used in recognition or recommendation systems may attract more users if they experience high accuracy but drive away those with less satisfaction, which may cause group proportion ps(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to change.

In this paper, we first explore the fairness properties of PS solutions in SDPP, i.e., examining whether 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Eqn. (1) have disparate impacts on different demographic groups. Specifically, we consider two fairness metrics: group-wise loss disparity △ℒ(t)superscriptsubscript△ℒ𝑡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}△ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [6, 19] and participation disparity △p(t)superscriptsubscript△𝑝𝑡\triangle_{p}^{(t)}△ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [8] measuring the difference of loss ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟s(t))ℒ𝜽superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and fraction ps(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT across different groups at round t𝑡titalic_t of an iterative algorithm. In examples with two groups 𝒮={a,b}𝒮𝑎𝑏\mathcal{S}=\{a,b\}caligraphic_S = { italic_a , italic_b }, the unfairness can be quantified as

△ℒ(t):=|ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟a(t))−ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟b(t))|,△p(t):=|pa(t)−pb(t)|.formulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptsubscript△ℒ𝑡ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑎𝑡ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑏𝑡assignsuperscriptsubscript△𝑝𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏𝑡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}:=\left|\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};% \mathcal{D}_{a}^{(t)})-\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{b}^{% (t)})\right|,~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\triangle_{p}^{(t)}:=\left|p_{a}^{(t)}-p_{b}^{(t)}% \right|.△ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := | caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | , △ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | . (4)

Unfairness & polarization effects in SDPP.

We first show (through two toy examples) that PS solutions 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in SDPP may have disparate impacts on different groups. Specifically, when finding 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using iterative algorithms introduced in Section 2, the process may incur severe polarization effects and exhibit unfairness, i.e., certain groups may get marginalized and diminish from the system, and group-wise loss disparity gets exacerbated during the iterative process.

Example 3.1 (Polarization effects of 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

Consider individuals from two groups a,b𝑎𝑏a,bitalic_a , italic_b whose participation in an ML system depends on their perceived loss, i.e., group fraction ps(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes based on the deployed ML model. Suppose individuals from group a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b have fixed data Z=za=1𝑍subscript𝑧𝑎1Z=z_{a}=1italic_Z = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and Z=zb=0𝑍subscript𝑧𝑏0Z=z_{b}=0italic_Z = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, respectively. Their initial group fractions are pa(0)=0.7,pb(0)=0.3formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎00.7superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏00.3p_{a}^{(0)}=0.7,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.3italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.7 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.3. Consider conventional RRM with mean squared error ℒ⁢(𝛉;𝒟(t))=∑s∈{a,b}ps(t)⁢(θ−zs)2ℒ𝛉superscript𝒟𝑡subscript𝑠𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡superscript𝜃subscript𝑧𝑠2\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t)})=\sum_{s\in\{a,b\}}p_{s}^{(t% )}(\theta-z_{s})^{2}caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_θ - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and transition T that satisfies pa(t+1)=pa(t)+0.1⋅[ℒ⁢(𝛉(t);𝒟b(t))−ℒ⁢(𝛉(t);𝒟a(t))],pb(t+1)=1−pa(t+1)formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎𝑡⋅0.1delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝛉𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑏𝑡ℒsuperscript𝛉𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑎𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏𝑡11superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎𝑡1p_{a}^{(t+1)}=p_{a}^{(t)}+0.1\cdot\left[\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};% \mathcal{D}_{b}^{(t)})-\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{a}^{% (t)})\right],p_{b}^{(t+1)}=1-p_{a}^{(t+1)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 0.1 ⋅ [ caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., group fraction decreases if the group has higher loss). It is easy to see that pa(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎𝑡p_{a}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (resp. pb(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏𝑡p_{b}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) monotonically increases (resp. decreases) in t𝑡titalic_t, and the PS solution solely contains people from group a𝑎aitalic_a (see Fig. 1).

Example 3.2 (Exacerbated group-wise loss disparity).

Consider individuals from two groups a,b𝑎𝑏a,bitalic_a , italic_b who are subject to certain ML decisions; each has an initial feature X∼Uniform⁢(0,1)similar-to𝑋Uniform01X\sim\text{Uniform}(0,1)italic_X ∼ Uniform ( 0 , 1 ) and a binary label Y=𝟙⁢(X≥0.5)∈{0,1}𝑌1𝑋0.501Y=\mathbbm{1}(X\geq 0.5)\in\{0,1\}italic_Y = blackboard_1 ( italic_X ≥ 0.5 ) ∈ { 0 , 1 }. Suppose the population has fixed group fractions pa=0.7,pb=0.3formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑎0.7subscript𝑝𝑏0.3p_{a}=0.7,p_{b}=0.3italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.7 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.3, but individuals may strategically manipulate their features to increase their chances of receiving favorable ML decisions, i.e., distribution of each group 𝒟s(t)superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes based on ML model. Following the individual response model in [20, 16], we suppose individuals from two groups have certain effort budgets ηa=0.2,ηb=0.01formulae-sequencesubscript𝜂𝑎0.2subscript𝜂𝑏0.01\eta_{a}=0.2,\eta_{b}=0.01italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.2 , italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01 that can be used to improve their features Xs(t+1)=Xs(t)+ηs⋅𝛉(t)superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑡⋅subscript𝜂𝑠superscript𝛉𝑡X_{s}^{(t+1)}=X_{s}^{(t)}+\eta_{s}\cdot\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Consider RRM iterative algorithm where the model parameter 𝛉(t)superscript𝛉𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is updated to maximize prediction accuracy Pr⁡(𝟙⁢(X≥𝛉(t))=Y(t))Pr1𝑋superscript𝛉𝑡superscript𝑌𝑡\Pr(\mathbbm{1}(X\geq\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})=Y^{(t)})roman_Pr ( blackboard_1 ( italic_X ≥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Given an initial model 𝛉(0)=0.5superscript𝛉00.5\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)}=0.5bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5, it is trivial to see that 𝛉(t)superscript𝛉𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT increases over time to be robust against manipulation until converges to PS solution 𝛉PS=0.625superscript𝛉PS0.625\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}=0.625bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.625 (see Fig. 1). However, at the PS solution, the accuracy for group a𝑎aitalic_a is 1 but is only 0.880.880.880.88 for group b𝑏bitalic_b.

4 Fair-PS Solutions and Fairness Mechanisms

Section 3 shows that without fairness consideration, PS solution of SDPP may incur polarization effects and have disparate impacts on different groups, i.e., when finding 𝜽PSsuperscript𝜽PS\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using iterative algorithms such as RRM, group-wise loss disparity △ℒ(t)superscriptsubscript△ℒ𝑡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}△ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and participation disparity △p(t)superscriptsubscript△𝑝𝑡\triangle_{p}^{(t)}△ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT may get exacerbated and converge to an unfair state. In this section, we address unfairness issues in SDPP. One straightforward idea is to directly apply the fairness mechanisms at every round of the iterative algorithms introduced in Section 2. However, we will show that although such methods are effective in conventional supervised learning, they can disrupt the stability and the iterative algorithms may no longer converge.

4.1 Fairness mechanisms and Fair-PS solutions

Many fairness mechanisms have been proposed in supervised learning to mitigate group-wise loss disparity and participation disparity. We consider two categories commonly used in the literature: regularization method and sample re-weighting method, as detailed below.

  1. 1.

    Fairness via regularization: It adds a regularization/penalty term to the original learning objective function ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟)ℒ𝜽𝒟\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ), which penalizes the violation of fairness [9, 10]. The fair objective function is

    ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ):=ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟)+𝒫⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ),assignsubscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟𝜌ℒ𝜽𝒟𝒫𝜽𝒟𝜌\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho):=\mathcal{L}% (\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})+\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},% \rho),caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) := caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) + caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) , (5)

    where 𝒫⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ)𝒫𝜽𝒟𝜌\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) is the fair penalty term and the scalar ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0italic_ρ > 0 controls the strength of the penalty.

  2. 2.

    Fairness via sample re-weighting: It adjusts the weights of samples (possibly adversarially) and increases sample weights for disadvantaged groups [11, 12, 13]. One example is distributionally robust optimization (DRO) [18], which minimizes the worst-case loss and the fair objective is

    ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ):=max𝒟~∈ℬ⁢(𝒟,r⁢(ρ))⁡ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟~),assignsubscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟𝜌subscript~𝒟ℬ𝒟𝑟𝜌ℒ𝜽~𝒟\textstyle\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho):=% \max_{\tilde{\mathcal{D}}\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{D},r(\rho))}\mathcal{L}(% \boldsymbol{\theta};\tilde{\mathcal{D}}),caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) := roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_D , italic_r ( italic_ρ ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) , (6)

    where ℬ⁢(𝒟,r⁢(ρ)):={𝒟~|d⁢(𝒟,𝒟~)≤r⁢(ρ)}assignℬ𝒟𝑟𝜌conditional-set~𝒟𝑑𝒟~𝒟𝑟𝜌\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{D},r(\rho)):=\{\tilde{\mathcal{D}}|d(\mathcal{D},\tilde{% \mathcal{D}})\leq r(\rho)\}caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_D , italic_r ( italic_ρ ) ) := { over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG | italic_d ( caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) ≤ italic_r ( italic_ρ ) } denotes a distribution ball centered at 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D with radius r⁢(ρ)𝑟𝜌r(\rho)italic_r ( italic_ρ ) derived from the fair mechanism strength ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, and d𝑑ditalic_d is a distribution distance metric.

By optimizing a fair objective ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ)subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟𝜌\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ), existing fairness mechanisms can effectively mitigate unfairness in supervised learning with static data distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. However, it remains unclear how these methods would perform in SDPP when the model itself causes the data distribution shifts. Specifically, consider iterative algorithms introduced in Eqn. (3) that find PS solutions (e.g., RRM). Suppose we apply the above fairness mechanism at every round when updating the model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ, i.e., replacing 𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1))superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽ℒ𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with fair version 𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ)superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) in iterative algorithms. We ask: can such new iterative algorithms mitigate group-wise loss and participation disparity in SDPP and converge to a fair and stable solution?

Before answering the above question, we first define Fair-PS solutions for SDPP, at which both ML system and population distribution reach stability and unfairness is mitigated.

Definition 4.1 (Fair-PS solution).

We define (𝒟fairPS,𝜽fairPS)subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairsubscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfair(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as the Fair-PS solution to ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ)subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟𝜌\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) if

𝒟fairPS=T⁢(𝜽fairPS;𝒟fairPS),𝜽fairPS=argmin𝜽⁢ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟fairPS,ρ).formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairTsubscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfairsubscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairsubscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfair𝜽argminsubscriptℒfair𝜽subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair𝜌\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}=\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS% }}_{\textsf{fair}};\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}),~{}~{}~{}~{}% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}% {\operatorname{argmin}}~{}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\rho).caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = underbold_italic_θ start_ARG roman_argmin end_ARG caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) .

4.2 Existing designs fail to converge to Fair-PS solutions

We will use two examples to illustrate that the popular choices of fairness mechanisms used in previous literature may fail to achieve stability and fairness in SDPP. This includes (i) regularization method [9, 10] with group loss variance 𝒫⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ):=ρ⁢∑s∈𝒮ps⋅[ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟s)−ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟)]2assign𝒫𝜽𝒟𝜌𝜌subscript𝑠𝒮⋅subscript𝑝𝑠superscriptdelimited-[]ℒ𝜽subscript𝒟𝑠ℒ𝜽𝒟2\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho):=\rho\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}p% _{s}\cdot[\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s})-\mathcal{L}(% \boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})]^{2}caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) := italic_ρ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ [ caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the penalty term in Eqn. (5); and (ii) distributionally robust optimization (DRO) method [19, 21] with χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-distance metric d⁢(𝒟,𝒟~):=∫(d⁢𝒟d⁢𝒟~−1)2⁢𝑑𝒟~assign𝑑𝒟~𝒟superscript𝑑𝒟𝑑~𝒟12differential-d~𝒟d(\mathcal{D},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}):=\int\left(\frac{d\mathcal{D}}{d\tilde{% \mathcal{D}}}-1\right)^{2}d\tilde{\mathcal{D}}italic_d ( caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) := ∫ ( divide start_ARG italic_d caligraphic_D end_ARG start_ARG italic_d over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_ARG - 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG in Eqn. (6).

Example 4.2 (Group loss variance as penalty term).

Consider two groups a,b𝑎𝑏a,bitalic_a , italic_b with data Z=(X,Y)𝑍𝑋𝑌Z=(X,Y)italic_Z = ( italic_X , italic_Y ) and fixed group fractions pa=pb=0.5subscript𝑝𝑎subscript𝑝𝑏0.5p_{a}=p_{b}=0.5italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5. Suppose all samples in group a𝑎aitalic_a are (1,−1)11(1,-1)( 1 , - 1 ) and all samples in group b𝑏bitalic_b are (2,1)21(2,1)( 2 , 1 ). Consider squared loss function ℓ⁢(z;θ)=(y−hθ⁢(x))2=(y−θ⁢x)2ℓ𝑧𝜃superscript𝑦subscriptℎ𝜃𝑥2superscript𝑦𝜃𝑥2\ell(z;\theta)=(y-h_{\theta}(x))^{2}=(y-\theta x)^{2}roman_ℓ ( italic_z ; italic_θ ) = ( italic_y - italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_y - italic_θ italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which is strongly convex and jointly smooth. Under group loss variance penalty 𝒫⁢(𝛉;𝒟,ρ)𝒫𝛉𝒟𝜌\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_P ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ), we have ℒfair⁢(𝛉;𝒟,ρ)=2.5⁢θ2−θ+1+ρ⋅(2.25⁢θ4+9⁢θ2−9⁢θ3)subscriptℒfair𝛉𝒟𝜌2.5superscript𝜃2𝜃1⋅𝜌2.25superscript𝜃49superscript𝜃29superscript𝜃3\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)=2.5\theta^{2% }-\theta+1+\rho\cdot(2.25\theta^{4}+9\theta^{2}-9\theta^{3})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) = 2.5 italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_θ + 1 + italic_ρ ⋅ ( 2.25 italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 9 italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 9 italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). When ρ=0.6𝜌0.6\rho=0.6italic_ρ = 0.6, the second-order derivative ∇θ2ℒfair=16.2⁢θ2−32.4⁢θ+15.8subscriptsuperscript∇2𝜃subscriptℒfair16.2superscript𝜃232.4𝜃15.8\nabla^{2}_{\theta}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}=16.2\theta^{2}-32.4\theta+15.8∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 16.2 italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 32.4 italic_θ + 15.8 and is negative when θ=1𝜃1\theta=1italic_θ = 1. Because convexity of ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a necessary condition for iterative algorithms such as RRM to converge to a stable solution (by Lemma 2.4), adding group loss variance as a penalty at each round will disrupt the stability and the algorithm fails to find Fair-PS solutions. Appendix C.4 provides an empirical illustration of this.

Example 4.3 (Repeated DRO with χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-distance metric).

Consider two groups a,b𝑎𝑏a,bitalic_a , italic_b with fixed data za=1subscript𝑧𝑎1z_{a}=1italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and zb=−1subscript𝑧𝑏1z_{b}=-1italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 1 for all samples but group fractions pa(t)=0.5⋅(1+θ(t))superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎𝑡⋅0.51superscript𝜃𝑡p_{a}^{(t)}=0.5\cdot(1+\theta^{(t)})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5 ⋅ ( 1 + italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and pb(t)=0.5⋅(1−θ(t))superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏𝑡⋅0.51superscript𝜃𝑡p_{b}^{(t)}=0.5\cdot(1-\theta^{(t)})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5 ⋅ ( 1 - italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). pa(0)=0.4,pb(0)=0.6formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎00.4superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏00.6p_{a}^{(0)}=0.4,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.6italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6. Consider a mean estimation task where the model parameter θ(t+1):=arg⁡min𝛉⁡max𝒟~∈ℬ⁢(𝒟(t),r)⁡ℒ⁢(θ;𝒟~)assignsuperscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝛉subscript~𝒟ℬsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑟ℒ𝜃~𝒟{\theta}^{(t+1)}:=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\max_{\tilde{\mathcal{D}}\in% \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{D}^{(t)},r)}\mathcal{L}({\theta};\tilde{\mathcal{D}})italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_θ ; over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) is updated using DRO with mean squared error and χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-distance bound r=1/6𝑟16r=1/6italic_r = 1 / 6. Let qa(t),qb(t)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑎𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑏𝑡q_{a}^{(t)},q_{b}^{(t)}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the group fractions of "worst-case" distribution 𝒟~~𝒟\tilde{\mathcal{D}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. We have qa(0)=0.6,qb(0)=0.4formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑎00.6superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑏00.4q_{a}^{(0)}=0.6,q_{b}^{(0)}=0.4italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6 , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4 and θ(1)=arg⁡minθ⁡qa(0)⁢(1−θ)2+qb(0)⁢(1+θ)2=0.2superscript𝜃1subscript𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑎0superscript1𝜃2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑏0superscript1𝜃20.2\theta^{(1)}=\arg\min_{\theta}q_{a}^{(0)}(1-\theta)^{2}+q_{b}^{(0)}(1+\theta)^% {2}=0.2italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_θ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_θ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.2, which results in pa(1)=0.6,pb(1)=0.4formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎10.6superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏10.4p_{a}^{(1)}=0.6,p_{b}^{(1)}=0.4italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4. Since ℒa⁢(θ(1);za)<ℒb⁢(θ(1);zb)subscriptℒ𝑎superscript𝜃1subscript𝑧𝑎subscriptℒ𝑏superscript𝜃1subscript𝑧𝑏\mathcal{L}_{a}(\theta^{(1)};z_{a})<\mathcal{L}_{b}(\theta^{(1)};z_{b})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), DRO should minimize the risk of the "worst-case" distribution with qa(1)=0.4,qb(1)=0.6formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑎10.4superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑏10.6q_{a}^{(1)}=0.4,q_{b}^{(1)}=0.6italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4 , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6, i.e., θ(2)=arg⁡minθ⁡qa(1)⁢(1−θ)2+qb(1)⁢(1+θ)2=−0.2superscript𝜃2subscript𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑎1superscript1𝜃2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑏1superscript1𝜃20.2\theta^{(2)}=\arg\min_{\theta}q_{a}^{(1)}(1-\theta)^{2}+q_{b}^{(1)}(1+\theta)^% {2}=-0.2italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_θ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_θ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - 0.2. Repeating the procedure we will get pa(2)=0.4,pb(2)=0.6formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎20.4superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏20.6p_{a}^{(2)}=0.4,p_{b}^{(2)}=0.6italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6 and qa(2)=0.6,qb(2)=0.4formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑎20.6superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑏20.4q_{a}^{(2)}=0.6,q_{b}^{(2)}=0.4italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6 , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.4, θ(3)=0.2superscript𝜃30.2\theta^{(3)}=0.2italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.2. It turns out that repeated DRO results in θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT oscillating between 0.20.20.20.2 and −0.20.2-0.2- 0.2 and it never converges.

It is worth noting that DRO methods have been used in Hashimoto et al. [19] to mitigate group fraction disparity in repeated optimizations. However, it only improves fairness without any convergence guarantees to stable solutions. Peet-Pare et al. [21] repeatedly used DRO to improve fairness under PP settings, it only converges to a PS solution under strict assumptions that are hard to verify. Under milder conditions in Lemma 2.4, it may fail to converge as Example 4.3 illustrated.

4.3 Novel designs for fairness mechanism

Next, we introduce three novel fair objective functions ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ)subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟𝜌\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) for fairness mechanisms, of which two belong to regularization method and one is a sample re-weighting method. By replacing 𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1))superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽ℒ𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with the proposed fair update 𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ)superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) in Eqn. (3), the resulting iterative algorithms can converge to Fair-PS solutions.

Proposed fair regularization (with and without demographics). Depending on whether sensitive attributes S𝑆Sitalic_S are accessible during training, we propose two fairness penalty terms, as detailed below.

  1. 1.

    Group level fairness penalty: It updates model parameter 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at round t𝑡titalic_t by the following

    𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ):=ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1))+ρ⁢∑s∈𝒮ps(t−1)⁢[ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟s(t−1))]2superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌assignℒ𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌subscript𝑠𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑠superscriptdelimited-[]ℒ𝜽superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡12\textstyle\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}% }\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho):=% \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})+\rho\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}% }p^{(t-1)}_{s}[\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-1)})]^{2}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) := caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_ρ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (7)
  2. 2.

    Sample level fairness penalty without demographics: It updates model parameter 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at round t𝑡titalic_t as follows, which does not need the knowledge of sensitive attributes.

    𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ):=ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1))+ρ⁢𝔼Z∼𝒟(t−1)⁢[[ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)]2].superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌assignℒ𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌subscript𝔼similar-to𝑍superscript𝒟𝑡1delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-[]ℓ𝜽𝑍2\textstyle\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}% }\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho):=% \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})+\rho\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim% \mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}}\big{[}[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)]^{2}\big{]}.bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) := caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_ρ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z ∼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ [ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (8)

Proposed fair sample re-weighting. It updates model parameter 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at round t𝑡titalic_t as follows.

𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ):=∑s∈𝒮qs(t−1)⁢ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟s(t−1)),superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌assignsubscript𝑠𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑠𝑡1ℒ𝜽superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{% \theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},% \rho):=\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}q_{s}^{(t-1)}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};% \mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-1)}),bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (9)
with ⁢𝒒(t−1)=[qs(t−1)]s∈𝒮:=𝒑(t−1)+ρ⁢𝒍(t−1)‖𝒑(t−1)+ρ⁢𝒍(t−1)‖1⁢ and ⁢𝒍(t−1):=[ps(t−1)⁢ℒ⁢(𝜽(t−1);𝒟s(t−2))]s∈𝒮with superscript𝒒𝑡1subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑡1𝑠𝑠𝒮assignsuperscript𝒑𝑡1𝜌superscript𝒍𝑡1subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑡1𝜌superscript𝒍𝑡11 and superscript𝒍𝑡1assignsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡2𝑠𝒮\displaystyle\text{with }~{}\boldsymbol{q}^{(t-1)}=\left[q^{(t-1)}_{s}\right]_% {s\in\mathcal{S}}:=\frac{\boldsymbol{p}^{(t-1)}+\rho\boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}}{\|% \boldsymbol{p}^{(t-1)}+\rho\boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}\|_{1}}\text{ and }~{}% \boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}:=\left[p_{s}^{(t-1)}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t% -1)};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-2)})\right]_{s\in\mathcal{S}}with bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ρ bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ρ bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG and bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Unlike DRO methods in [22, 19] that require solving a min-max optimization at the current round, our re-weighting method only adjusts the weights for each group based on the group-wise losses in the previous round, which is more computationally efficient.

Comparison & discussion. Intuitively, compared to original ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1))ℒ𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), all three proposed fair objective functions ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ)subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) improves fairness at each round by assigning more weights to disadvantaged groups/samples (i.e., the groups/samples experiencing higher losses) in the upcoming update. Indeed, both sample level fairness penalty and fair sample re-weighting can be regarded as modifications of group level fairness penalty.

Comparing Eqn. (7) and (8), the two penalty terms get more similar when most individual samples in the disadvantaged (resp. advantaged) groups are also similarly disadvantaged (resp. advantaged). This is more likely to happen when each demographic group has a distribution with a small variance. For example, if the distribution of each group is a point mass, Eqn. (7) and (8) are identical.

Comparing Eqn. (7) and (9), we can rewrite Eqn. (9) as the following:

‖𝒑(t−1)+ρ⁢𝒍(t−1)‖1⁢ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ)=∑s∈𝒮ps(t−1)⁢(1+ρ)⁢ℒ⁢(𝜽(t−1);𝒟s(t−2))⁢ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟s(t−1)).subscriptnormsuperscript𝒑𝑡1𝜌superscript𝒍𝑡11subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌subscript𝑠𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡11𝜌ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡2ℒ𝜽superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡1\textstyle\|\boldsymbol{p}^{(t-1)}+\rho\boldsymbol{l}^{(t-1)}\|_{1}\mathcal{L}% _{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)=~{}\sum_{s\in% \mathcal{S}}p_{s}^{(t-1)}(1+\rho)\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t-1)};% \mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-2)})\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-1)% }).∥ bold_italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ρ bold_italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_ρ ) caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

We can see that the right-hand side will be a multiple of Eqn. (7) if we replace ℒ⁢(𝜽(t−1);𝒟s(t−2))ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡2\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t-1)};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-2)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟s(t−1))ℒ𝜽superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡1\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t-1)})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This means both equations yield the same θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when the population distribution does not change from t−2𝑡2t-2italic_t - 2 to t−1𝑡1t-1italic_t - 1, suggesting that the two approaches become more similar when the sensitivity of the transition mapping T is smaller, or equivalently, the distribution shift is milder. Finally, we also discuss designing fair objective functions generally in App. B.4.

5 Theoretical Analysis

Next, we show that by replacing update 𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒ⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1))superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽ℒ𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)})bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in Eqn. (3) with the fair update 𝜽(t)=argmin𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ)superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptargmin𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}=\operatorname{argmin}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{% L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) we proposed in Section 4.3, Fair-PS solutions (Definition 4.1) exist under certain conditions and the resulting iterative algorithms (see Algorithm 1) can converge to such Fair-PS solutions. We assume conditions in Lemma 2.4 hold in this section and there exists a unique PS solution in the original SDPP problem.

We first define a parameter β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta}over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG which will be frequently used in the theorems introduced below.

β~:={(2⁢ρ⁢ℓ¯+1)⁢β,for fair regularization method with group level (7) or sample level penalty (8) (ρ⁢ℓ¯+1)⁢β,for fair sample re-weighting method (9) assign~𝛽cases2𝜌¯ℓ1𝛽for fair regularization method with group level (7) or sample level penalty (8) otherwise𝜌¯ℓ1𝛽for fair sample re-weighting method (9) otherwise\tilde{\beta}:=\begin{cases}(2\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\beta,~{}~{}~{}\text{for % fair regularization method with group level \eqref{eq:squared_group_loss_% penalty} or sample level penalty \eqref{eq:fair_loss_sample_level} }\\ (\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\beta,~{}~{}~{}\text{for fair sample re-weighting % method \eqref{eq:fair_reweight} }\end{cases}over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG := { start_ROW start_CELL ( 2 italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_β , for fair regularization method with group level ( ) or sample level penalty ( ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_β , for fair sample re-weighting method ( ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW

where ℓ¯:=sup𝜽,Zℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)assign¯ℓsubscriptsupremum𝜽𝑍ℓ𝜽𝑍\overline{\ell}:=\sup_{\boldsymbol{\theta},Z}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG := roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ , italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ). We can identify conditions under which a unique Fair-PS solution exists.

Proposition 5.1 (Existence of unique Fair-PS solution).

For a given population with initial distribution 𝒟(0)superscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}^{(0)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the proposed fair mechanism ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with strength ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, there is a unique Fair-PS solution if ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1. Moreover, (𝒟fairPS,𝛉fairPS)subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairsubscriptsuperscript𝛉PSfair(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is independent of the choice of repeated deployment schema.

Although the choice of repeated deployment schema does not affect the Fair-PS solution (𝒟fairPS,𝜽fairPS)subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairsubscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfair(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), it influences the convergence rate of the iterative algorithms as stated in Theorem 5.2.

Theorem 5.2 (Convergence of Fair-RRM).

Under conventional deployment schema, Algorithm 1 converges to the Fair-PS solution at a linear rate if ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1; under k𝑘kitalic_k-delayed deployment schema, Algorithm 1 converges to the Fair-PS solution at a linear rate for any k𝑘kitalic_k if ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1−ϵitalic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1italic-ϵ\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1-\epsilonitalic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1 - italic_ϵ; Particularly, under delayed deployment schema when r=log−1⁡(1ϵ)⁢log⁡(𝒲1⁢(𝒟(0),𝒟(1))δ)𝑟superscript11italic-ϵsubscript𝒲1superscript𝒟0superscript𝒟1𝛿r=\log^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)\log\left(\frac{\mathcal{W}_{1}(% \mathcal{D}^{(0)},\mathcal{D}^{(1)})}{\delta}\right)italic_r = roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ), Algorithm 1 converges to a radius δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ of the Fair-PS solution (i.e., ‖𝛉(t)−𝛉fairPS‖2≤δsubscriptnormsuperscript𝛉𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝛉PSfair2𝛿\|\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\|_% {2}\leq\delta∥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_δ and 𝒲1⁢(𝒟⁢(𝛉(t)),𝒟fairPS)≤δsubscript𝒲1𝒟superscript𝛉𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair𝛿\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}),\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}% _{\textsf{fair}})\leq\deltacaligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_δ) in 𝒪⁢(log2⁡1δ)𝒪superscript21𝛿\mathcal{O}(\log^{2}\frac{1}{\delta})caligraphic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) steps if ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1.

In Appendix B.3, we extend the Algorithm 1 to practical scenarios when data distribution is inaccessible.
