We provide the algorithm fair repeated empirical risk minimization (Fair-RERM) where only limited data samples are available from 𝒟(t)superscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and analyze its sample complexity in Theorem B.3.

Impacts of strength of fair mechanism ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ. Theorem 5.2 and B.3 show that repeatedly minimizing ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟(t−1),ρ)subscriptℒfair𝜽superscript𝒟𝑡1𝜌\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) on evolving data sequence can lead the system converging to a Fair-PS solution. Note that ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ controls the strength of fairness and different ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ could result in different (𝜽fairPS,𝒟fairPS)subscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfairsubscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}})( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In conventional supervised learning with static data distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, it is trivial to see that larger ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ in ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟,ρ)subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟𝜌\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D},\rho)caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D , italic_ρ ) will lead to a fairer solution [6]. However, in SDPP with model-dependent distribution shifts, the impact of ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ on unfairness is less straightforward. Because both data distribution 𝒟fairPSsubscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and model 𝜽fairPSsubscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfair\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depend on ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, analyzing how group-wise disparity would change as ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ varies can be highly non-trivial and has not been studied in PP literature (Appendix D.4 provides more discussion).

Next, we initiate the study for fair mechanism in Eqn. (7) with group-level fairness penalty and rigorously show that the larger ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ can lead to smaller group-wise loss disparity at the Fair-PS solution. We will focus on a special case of user retention dynamics [19, 2] with two groups s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\}italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b }, where the group distribution 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is fixed but the fraction ps(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡p_{s}^{(t)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes based on group loss ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟s)ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{s})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) during repeated risk minimization process.

Assumption 5.3.

At each round, the group that is majority also experiences lower expected loss, i.e., arg⁡maxs∈{a,b}⁡pst=arg⁡mins∈{a,b}⁡ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟s)subscript𝑠𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡subscript𝑠𝑎𝑏ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝒟𝑠\arg\max_{s\in\{a,b\}}p_{s}^{t}=\arg\min_{s\in\{a,b\}}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{% \theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{s})roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Moreover, for any two models deployed on population 𝒟(t)superscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the model with larger loss disparity △ℒ(t)superscriptsubscript△ℒ𝑡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}△ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT leads to higher group fraction disparity △p(t+1)subscriptsuperscript△𝑡1𝑝\triangle^{(t+1)}_{p}△ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time t+1𝑡1t+1italic_t + 1.

Assumption 5.3 is natural: in fields such as recognition or recommendation systems, the minority group contributing less training data suffers from higher loss and has a lower retention rate.

Theorem 5.4 (Larger ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ leads to stronger fairness).

Denote Fair-PS solution (𝛉fairPS⁢(ρ),𝒟fairPS⁢(ρ))subscriptsuperscript𝛉PSfair𝜌subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair𝜌\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right),% \mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right)\right)( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) ) as a function of ρ≥0𝜌0\rho\geq 0italic_ρ ≥ 0. Let △fair,ℒPS⁢(ρ)subscriptsuperscript△PSfairℒ𝜌\triangle^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair},\mathcal{L}}(\rho)△ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair , caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) be the group-wise loss disparity of 𝛉fairPS⁢(ρ)subscriptsuperscript𝛉PSfair𝜌\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right)bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) evaluated over distribution 𝒟fairPS⁢(ρ)subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair𝜌\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\left(\rho\right)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) as defined in Eqn. (4). Under Assumption 5.3, △fair,ℒPS⁢(ρ)subscriptsuperscript△PSfairℒ𝜌\triangle^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair},\mathcal{L}}(\rho)△ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair , caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) is non-increasing in ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ.

6 Numerical Results

This section empirically evaluates the proposed methods on synthetic and real-world data (including credit data [4, 23] and MNIST data [24]) under semi-synthesized performative shifts. We run all experiments with multiple random seeds and visualize the standard error with the shaded area. Due to page limits, more experiments are presented in Appendix C.

Performative Gaussian mean estimation. We generate a synthetic dataset of 10000100001000010000 samples from two groups s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\}italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } with initial group fractions pa(0)=0.3,pb(0)=0.7formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎00.3superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏00.7p_{a}^{(0)}=0.3,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.7italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.3 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.7 and target values ya=0.3+ϵ,yb=0.7+ϵformulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑎0.3italic-ϵsubscript𝑦𝑏0.7italic-ϵy_{a}=0.3+\epsilon,y_{b}=0.7+\epsilonitalic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.3 + italic_ϵ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.7 + italic_ϵ, where ϵ∼𝒩⁢(0,0.05)similar-toitalic-ϵ𝒩00.05\epsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(0,0.05)italic_ϵ ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 0.05 ). We consider user retention dynamics where the group fraction ps(t+1)=ℛ⁢(s,t)∑s′∈{a,b}ℛ⁢(s′,t)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑠ℛ𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑎𝑏ℛsuperscript𝑠′𝑡p^{(t+1)}_{s}=\frac{\mathcal{R}(s,t)}{\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\{a,b\}}\mathcal{R}(s% ^{\prime},t)}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG caligraphic_R ( italic_s , italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) end_ARG changes based on group-wise loss. Here ℛ⁢(s,t)=(1−∑s′∈{a,b}ps′min)×12⁢(pst+ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟−s(t))ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟−s(t))+ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟s(t)))+psminℛ𝑠𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑎𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑝superscript𝑠′12superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}(s,t)=\left(1-\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\{a,b\}}p^{\min}_{s^{\prime}}% \right)\times\frac{1}{2}\left(p_{s}^{t}+\frac{\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^% {(t)};\mathcal{D}_{-s}^{(t)})}{\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{% D}_{-s}^{(t)})+\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)})}% \right)+p_{s}^{\min}caligraphic_R ( italic_s , italic_t ) = ( 1 - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) × divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where psmin=0.02superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠0.02p_{s}^{\min}=0.02italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.02 is the minimum group fraction that ensures the sensitivity of the transition mapping T is bounded, and −s={a,b}∖s𝑠𝑎𝑏𝑠-s=\{a,b\}\setminus s- italic_s = { italic_a , italic_b } ∖ italic_s. We perform the mean estimation task and train multiple linear regression models using RERM and Fair-RERM, including regularization methods with group-level penalty (Fair-RERM-GLP), sample-level penalty (Fair-RERM-SLP) and sample re-weighting method (Fair-RERM-RW). We perform 30303030 rounds of empirical risk minimization on 7777 different random seeds. Fig. 2(a) illustrates the evolution of group-wise loss disparity △ℒ(t)superscriptsubscript△ℒ𝑡\triangle_{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)}△ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Fig. 2(b) shows the evolution of the minority group fraction (i.e., the group with the lower fraction at the stable point). The blue lines in both figures demonstrate that the PS solution of the regular RERM has the highest unfairness and the most polarized group fractions, while the Fair-PS solution is fairer and the higher ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ results in stronger fairness, implying Fair-RERM is effective in mitigating polarization effects and unfairness. We also note that among all three methods, the sample re-weighting method (Fair-RERM-RW) seems to yield better fairness control than others under this setting.

Credit data retention dynamics with strategic behaviors. We use the Give me some credit data [23] consisting of features X∈ℝ10𝑋superscriptℝ10X\in\mathbb{R}^{10}italic_X ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to measure individuals’ creditworthiness Y∈{0,1}𝑌01Y\in\{0,1\}italic_Y ∈ { 0 , 1 } which has been widely used in performative prediction and strategic classification literature [4, 15]. We preprocessed the data similarly to Perdomo et al. [4] and divided individuals into two groups s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\}italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } based on the age attribute. Next, we assume there is a newly established credit rating agency performing RERM and Fair-RERM with logistic classification models to predict individuals’ creditworthiness. Similar to the previous experiment, we assume the group-wise loss in round t𝑡titalic_t will affect the group fraction at t+1𝑡1t+1italic_t + 1. Meanwhile, we assume there is a subset of features Xs∈Xsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑋X_{s}\in Xitalic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_X which individuals can change strategically to Xs′superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠′X_{s}^{\prime}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT based on the current model parameters θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ. Specifically, Xs′=Xs−ϵ⋅θssuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠′subscript𝑋𝑠⋅italic-ϵsubscript𝜃𝑠X_{s}^{\prime}=X_{s}-\epsilon\cdot\theta_{s}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ϵ ⋅ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where θssubscript𝜃𝑠\theta_{s}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the subset of θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ with respect to Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ϵ=0.1italic-ϵ0.1\epsilon=0.1italic_ϵ = 0.1. With the dynamics involving both retention and strategic behaviors, we can visualize the dynamics of unfairness under RERM and Fair-RERM in Fig. 3. All results demonstrate the effectiveness of our methods. The regularization method with sample level penalty (Fair-RERM-SLP) seems to be more effective under this setting.

Performative MNIST classification. We next consider MNIST data [24] consisting of handwritten digits images. We randomly select 1000 images as the training set and divide them into 2 groups, where the first group contains all images with digits from 00 to 4444 and the second includes digits from 5555 to 9999. We consider the same group fraction dynamics as before with psmin=0.1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠0.1p_{s}^{\min}=0.1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.1 for both groups. Using a 2-layer MLP (the loss function violates conditions in Lemma 2.4) for risk minimization, we perform RERM and Fair-RERM for 50505050 rounds. Fig. 4(a) and 4(b) verify that Fair-RERM can still improve fairness at the PS solution. Both plots demonstrate that unfairness is the largest without fairness interventions and Fair-RERM is more effective with larger ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ. Unlike the experiments on synthetic and credit data, this set of experiments does not have a convergence guarantee because conditions for theorems are violated under 2-layer MLP, e.g., the black and red lines (ρ=0.3𝜌0.3\rho=0.3italic_ρ = 0.3) of Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM-GLP are unstable. However, the results suggest that our fairness mechanisms may still be useful in practice with deep learning models.

7 Conclusions & Societal Impacts

Our work reveals the unfairness issues of the PS solutions of PP. We then propose novel fairness-aware algorithms to find Fair-PS solutions with the convergence holds under mild assumptions, which will facilitate trustworthy machine learning since PP has broad applications on human-related decisions ranging from college admission and loan approval to hiring practice. Meaningful future directions include relaxing the conditions for the convergence of fairness mechanisms or expanding the mechanisms to deep learning settings.

  • Miller et al. [2021] John Miller, Juan C. Perdomo, and Tijana Zrnic. Outside the Echo Chamber: Optimizing the Performative Risk. arXiv:2102.08570 [cs, stat], June 2021. URL http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.08570. arXiv: 2102.08570.
  • Izzo et al. [2021] Zachary Izzo, Lexing Ying, and James Zou. How to learn when data reacts to your model: Performative gradient descent. CoRR, 2021. arXiv: 2102.07698.
  • Hardt and Mendler-Dünner [2023] Moritz Hardt and Celestine Mendler-Dünner. Performative prediction: Past and future. arXiv preprint arXiv:2310.16608, 2023.
  • Kamishima et al. [2011] Toshihiro Kamishima, Shotaro Akaho, and Jun Sakuma. Fairness-aware learning through regularization approach. In 2011 IEEE 11th International Conference on Data Mining Workshops, pages 643–650, 2011. doi: 10.1109/ICDMW.2011.83.
  • Zafar et al. [2017] Muhammad Bilal Zafar, Isabel Valera, Manuel Gomez Rodriguez, and Krishna P Gummadi. Fairness beyond disparate treatment & disparate impact: Learning classification without disparate mistreatment. In Proceedings of the 26th international conference on world wide web, pages 1171–1180, 2017.
  • Guldogan et al. [2022] Ozgur Guldogan, Yuchen Zeng, Jy-yong Sohn, Ramtin Pedarsani, and Kangwook Lee. Equal improvability: A new fairness notion considering the long-term impact. arXiv preprint arXiv:2210.06732, 2022.
  • Milli et al. [2018] Smitha Milli, John Miller, Anca D. Dragan, and Moritz Hardt. The social cost of strategic classification, 2018.
  • Hu et al. [2019] Lily Hu, Nicole Immorlica, and Jennifer Wortman Vaughan. The disparate effects of strategic manipulation. In ACM Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency, Atlanta, Georgia, 2019.
  • Zhang et al. [2020] Xueru Zhang, Ruibo Tu, Yang Liu, Mingyan Liu, Hedvig Kjellström, Kun Zhang, and Cheng Zhang. How do fair decisions fare in long-term qualification? In Proceedings of the 34th International Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems, NIPS’20, Red Hook, NY, USA, 2020. Curran Associates Inc. ISBN 9781713829546.
  • Bubeck [2015] Sébastien Bubeck. Convex optimization: Algorithms and complexity. Found. Trends Mach. Learn., 8(3–4):231–357, nov 2015. ISSN 1935-8237. doi: 10.1561/2200000050. URL https://doi.org/10.1561/2200000050.
  • Fournier and Guillin [2015] Nicolas Fournier and Arnaud Guillin. On the rate of convergence in Wasserstein distance of the empirical measure. Probability Theory and Related Fields, 162(3-4):707, August 2015. URL https://hal.science/hal-00915365.

Appendix A Related Works

Performative Prediction. Proposed by Perdomo et al. [4], Performative prediction focuses on machine learning problems where the model deployments influence the data distribution, and the common application scenarios include strategic classification [1, 25, 26, 27] and predictive policing [28]. Perdomo et al. [4] formulated the problem and proposed repeated risk minimization (RRM) to ensure the convergence of model parameters to a stable point under a set of sufficient and necessary conditions. Mendler-Dünner et al. [29] presented convergence results on stochastic performative optimization. Subsequent work either strived to relax the convergence condition [30, 31] or develop methods to ensure the convergence to performative optimal points under special cases [32, 33]. Brown et al. [5] extended performative prediction to stateful settings where the current data distribution is determined by both the previous states and the deployed model. For more related works on PP, we refer to this survey [34].

Long-term fairness. There is a large line of work on long-term fairness in machine learning, where we mainly refer to distributionally robust optimization (DRO) [12, 13] and soft fair regularizers [35, 36, 37]. DRO refers to the optimization problem where the loss is minimized on the worst-case distribution around current data distribution [12, 13], while soft fair regularizers are often used in traditional fair optimization frameworks to penalize unfairness. Only a few pieces of literature touched on fairness problems under performative prediction settings. [38, 39, 17, 40] focused on long-term fairness settings under strategic classification similar to Example 3.2. Zezulka and Genin [14] pointed out fairness issues in performative prediction and formulated it within causal graphs. Hu and Zhang [15] also used causality-based models to formulate and ensure short-term and long-term fairness in performative prediction, incurring strong assumptions and expensive computational costs. Raab et al. [8] studied a special case where only the agents’ retention rates are performative. Peet-Pare et al. [21] proposed to use distributionally robust optimization (DRO) to promote fairness in performative prediction, but they proposed assumptions that are hard to verify and can not be derived from other commonly accepted assumptions in PP.

Appendix B Further Elaboration on the Concepts

Here we include the notation table and a Venn diagram to help the readers better understand the technical details of our paper.

B.1 Notation Table

B.2 Venn Diagram of Concepts in PP

We present a Venn diagram of different PP cases in Figure 5. Within the broad concept of PP, we specifically characterize 3 practical concepts in real-world problems, namely the (1) state-dependent performative shifts, (2) performative retention dynamics, and (3) performative distribution shifts. These concepts represent different dimensions to partition the PP problems.

Performative Retention Dynamics (PRD).

Previous works that study long-term fairness [2, 40] mostly assume there to be model-dependent retention rate/population fraction pssubscript𝑝𝑠p_{s}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT changes, which can all be formulated as PRD problems. Recommendation systems are typical application scenarios of SDPP and PRD since the population fraction in the next iteration depends on both the current population and the current model. The better recommendation model captures a certain user group’s interest, the more likely this user group will have high retention rate.

Example B.1.

(User retention) Suppose two demographic groups a,b𝑎𝑏a,bitalic_a , italic_b each follow a static distribution 𝒟asubscript𝒟𝑎\mathcal{D}_{a}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒟bsubscript𝒟𝑏\mathcal{D}_{b}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but their fraction in the population changes over time, and thus the overall data distribution is dynamic. Specifically, let psm⁢i⁢nsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑚𝑖𝑛p_{s}^{min}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be control variables to limit the minimum fraction of group s𝑠sitalic_s, and their retention rate is determined by a retention function πs⁢(𝛉(t))subscript𝜋𝑠superscript𝛉𝑡\pi_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then we have

ps(t):=ps(t−1)⁢πs⁢(𝜽(t))+psm⁢i⁢n∑s′(ps′(t−1)⁢πs′⁢(𝜽(t))+ps′m⁢i⁢n),𝒟(t)=∑sps(t)⁢𝒟s,formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑠subscript𝜋𝑠superscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑚𝑖𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑠′subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1superscript𝑠′subscript𝜋superscript𝑠′superscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝superscript𝑠′𝑚𝑖𝑛superscript𝒟𝑡subscript𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑠subscript𝒟𝑠p^{(t)}_{s}:=\frac{p^{(t-1)}_{s}\pi_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})+p_{s}^{min}% }{\sum_{s^{\prime}}(p^{(t-1)}_{s^{\prime}}\pi_{s^{\prime}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}% ^{(t)})+p_{s^{\prime}}^{min})},~{}~{}\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\sum_{s}p^{(t)}_{s}% \mathcal{D}_{s},italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t -
