which can be modeled by PP in the SDPP setting.

Performative Distribution Shifts (PDS).

In this paper, PDS specifically means in each group, the data distribution 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT shifts with the decision models, e.g., in strategic classification, users strategically manipulate their features for better decision outcomes. In recommendation systems, where creators strategically manipulate their features for better decision outcomes from the model [1], and users’ interests can be shifted by the recommended items.

We present a practical example of PP in addition to the one in the main article.

Example B.2.

(Partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) as PDS [40]) The population fractions of the two groups pssubscript𝑝𝑠p_{s}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are static, i.e., 𝒟(t)=∑sps⁢𝒟s(t)superscript𝒟𝑡subscript𝑠subscript𝑝𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡\mathcal{D}^{(t)}=\sum_{s}p_{s}\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, but the feature distribution changes with the deployed decision model, and such changes follow a POMDP as shown in Figure 6.

Specifically, within each group, there are two sub-populations, qualified and disqualified, e.g., the qualified sub-population in group a𝑎aitalic_a satisfies y=1,s=aformulae-sequence𝑦1𝑠𝑎y=1,s=aitalic_y = 1 , italic_s = italic_a. Each sub-population has a static distribution, 𝒟s,ysubscript𝒟𝑠𝑦\mathcal{D}_{s,y}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but each group’s distribution is dynamic and determined by

𝒟s(t)=∑yαs,y(t)⁢𝒟s,y,αs,y(t):=ℙ⁢(Y(t)=1|S=s),formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑡subscript𝑦subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑡𝑠𝑦subscript𝒟𝑠𝑦assignsubscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑡𝑠𝑦ℙsuperscript𝑌𝑡conditional1𝑆𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s}^{(t)}=\sum_{y}\alpha^{(t)}_{s,y}\mathcal{D}_{s,y},~{}~{}\alpha% ^{(t)}_{s,y}:=\mathbb{P}(Y^{(t)}=1|S=s),caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := blackboard_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 | italic_S = italic_s ) , (11)

where Y(t)superscript𝑌𝑡Y^{(t)}italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the random variable of the agent’s true label at time step t𝑡titalic_t. The POMDP assumes the decision model and the sensitive attribute jointly determine the distribution of the true label distribution at the next time step, and we have

αs,1(t)=∑y=01αs,y(t−1)⁢ℙ(Y(t)=1|Y(t−1)=y,𝜽=𝜽(t),S=s)⏟from POMDP,\alpha^{(t)}_{s,1}=\sum_{y=0}^{1}\alpha^{(t-1)}_{s,y}\underbrace{\mathbb{P}(Y^% {(t)}=1|Y^{(t-1)}=y,\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)},S=s)}_{\text% {from POMDP}},italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under⏟ start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 | italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_y , bold_italic_θ = bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_S = italic_s ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT from POMDP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (12)

and we can similarly write out the dynamics of all the αs,y(t)subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑡𝑠𝑦\alpha^{(t)}_{s,y}italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT terms and thus the transition mapping T𝑇Titalic_T as a PDS problem.

B.3 Fair-RERM

Here we provide the algorithm for the Fair-RERM class and the results of its sample complexity.

Theorem B.3 (Convergence of fair-RERM).

Suppose ∃α>1,μ>0formulae-sequence𝛼1𝜇0\exists\alpha>1,\mu>0∃ italic_α > 1 , italic_μ > 0 such that ∫ℝmeμ⁢|x|α⁢Z⁢𝑑xsubscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑚superscript𝑒𝜇superscript𝑥𝛼𝑍differential-d𝑥\int_{\mathbb{R}^{m}}e^{\mu|x|^{\alpha}}Zdx∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ | italic_x | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Z italic_d italic_x is finite ∀Z∈△⁢(𝒵)for-all𝑍△𝒵\forall Z\in\triangle(\mathcal{Z})∀ italic_Z ∈ △ ( caligraphic_Z ). For a given convergence radius δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1)italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), take nt=𝒪⁢(log⁡(t/p)(ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)⁢δ)m)subscript𝑛𝑡𝒪𝑡𝑝superscriptitalic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾𝛿𝑚n_{t}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\log(t/p)}{(\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)% \delta)^{m}}\right)italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log ( italic_t / italic_p ) end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) italic_δ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) samples at t𝑡titalic_t. If 2⁢ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<12italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾12\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<12 italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1, then with probability 1−p1𝑝1-p1 - italic_p, the iterates of fair-RERM are within a radius δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ of the Fair-PS solution for t≥(1−2ϵ(1+β~/γ)O(log(1/δ))t\geq(1-2\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)O(\log(1/\delta))italic_t ≥ ( 1 - 2 italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) italic_O ( roman_log ( 1 / italic_δ ) ).

B.4 General guidance of designing fairness objectives under the SDPP setting

The key to designing a fairness objective while ensuring the convergence of the iterative algorithm is to ensure the convexity of the fairness penalty. Example 4.2 shows that group loss variance cannot preserve the convexity of ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so it fails to be a plausible objective. This implies that each penalty term in terms of P=g⁢(ℒ)𝑃𝑔ℒP=g(\mathcal{L})italic_P = italic_g ( caligraphic_L ) where the convexity of P𝑃Pitalic_P is ensured can be a fairness objective. However, it can still be highly non-trivial to design a fair objective in this form due to the following reasons: (i) it is hard to design an objective as interpretable as the ones we mentioned in Section 4. The squared loss as a penalty term is well-motivated and directly penalizes the groups/samples with the higher losses; (ii) It becomes more difficult to obtain the concrete parameters for the convergence guarantee. For example, ℓ¯¯ℓ\bar{\ell}over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG in Section 5 becomes the upper bound of ∂g∂ℓ𝑔ℓ\frac{\partial g}{\partial\ell}divide start_ARG ∂ italic_g end_ARG start_ARG ∂ roman_ℓ end_ARG and this may be hard to obtain and interpret. Overall, we see the formulations in Section 4 as more appropriate choices.

B.5 Only Measure Fairness at PS Solution

We provide an example to illustrate that fairness is not guaranteed even if we ensure instantaneous fairness without stability being achieved.

Example B.4.

(Fairness violation due to performative shifts) Consider a binary strategic classification problem with two groups a,b𝑎𝑏a,bitalic_a , italic_b and is a threshold model hθ⁢(X)=𝟙⁢{X≥θ}subscriptℎ𝜃𝑋1𝑋𝜃h_{\theta}(X)=\mathbbm{1}\{X\geq\theta\}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) = blackboard_1 { italic_X ≥ italic_θ }. pa,pbsubscript𝑝𝑎subscript𝑝𝑏p_{a},p_{b}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are fixed and both groups satisfy ℙ⁢(Y(t)=1)=min⁡{0,max⁡{X(t),1}}ℙsuperscript𝑌𝑡10superscript𝑋𝑡1\mathbb{P}(Y^{(t)}=1)=\min\{0,\max\{X^{(t)},1\}\}blackboard_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 ) = roman_min { 0 , roman_max { italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 1 } }, and the transitions satisfy X(t)=X(0)+(0.1+0.1⋅𝟏⁢{s=a})⁢θ(t)superscript𝑋𝑡superscript𝑋00.1⋅0.11𝑠𝑎superscript𝜃𝑡X^{(t)}=X^{(0)}+(0.1+0.1\cdot\boldsymbol{1}\{s=a\})\theta^{(t)}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( 0.1 + 0.1 ⋅ bold_1 { italic_s = italic_a } ) italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT but do not result in any changes in labels. If at t=0𝑡0t=0italic_t = 0, both groups have features X(0)superscript𝑋0X^{(0)}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT subject to uniform distribution on [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], then any θ=0.5𝜃0.5\theta=0.5italic_θ = 0.5 satisfies accuracy parity. However, at t=1𝑡1t=1italic_t = 1, group a𝑎aitalic_a has a shifted distribution, resulting in θ=0.5𝜃0.5\theta=0.5italic_θ = 0.5 to be unfair.

Appendix C Additional Experiments

All experiments are run on the CPU of a Macbook Pro with Apple M1 Pro chip and 16GB memory. We use Python 3.9 for all tasks. For datasets, Yann LeCun and Corinna Cortes hold the copyright of MNIST, which is a derivative work from original NIST datasets. MNIST dataset is made available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 license; the credit dataset has been published by Kaggle [23]; In Appendix C.1, we visualize the convergence of performative loss for all the above experiments. In Appendix C.3, we perform experiments on a performative Gaussian data classification task. In Appendix C.2, we conduct experiments on 3 groups. In Appendix C.4, we visualize the unconvergence of the fairness penalty using group loss variance as a complementary to Example 4.2; Finally, we examine the k-delayed schema on all our fairness mechanisms on Credit data in Appendix C.5 and obtain the similar results.

C.1 Model Convergence in Main Experiments

In this section, we provide visualizations of the convergence of performative loss for all experiments of the main paper in Fig. 12. Importantly, Fig. 12(d) demonstrates the unconvergence of Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM-GLP when ρ=0.3𝜌0.3\rho=0.3italic_ρ = 0.3.

C.2 Gaussian Mean Estimation with Multiple Groups

In this section, we present the experimental results on the Gaussian mean estimation task with 3 groups s∈{a,b,c}𝑠𝑎𝑏𝑐s\in\{a,b,c\}italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b , italic_c } where pa(0)=0.15,pb(0)=0.25,pc(0)=0.6formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎00.15formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏00.25superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑐00.6p_{a}^{(0)}=0.15,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.25,p_{c}^{(0)}=0.6italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.15 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.25 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.6 with different target values. We let ya=0.3+ϵ,yb=0.5+ϵ,yc=0.7+ϵformulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑎0.3italic-ϵformulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑏0.5italic-ϵsubscript𝑦𝑐0.7italic-ϵy_{a}=0.3+\epsilon,y_{b}=0.5+\epsilon,y_{c}=0.7+\epsilonitalic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.3 + italic_ϵ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5 + italic_ϵ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.7 + italic_ϵ where ϵ∼𝒩⁢(0,0.05)similar-toitalic-ϵ𝒩00.05\epsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(0,0.05)italic_ϵ ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 0.05 ). At the beginning, the Group fraction pa(0)=0.3,pb(0)=0.7formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑎00.3superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑏00.7p_{a}^{(0)}=0.3,p_{b}^{(0)}=0.7italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.3 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.7, and the minimum group fraction for each group is pm⁢i⁢n={0.1,0.1}superscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛0.10.1p^{min}=\{0.1,0.1\}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { 0.1 , 0.1 }. At each time t𝑡titalic_t, denote ℛ⁢(s,t)=(1−∑s′∈{a,b}ps′m⁢i⁢n)×12⁢(pst+ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟is(t))∑s′ℒ⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟s′(t)))+psm⁢i⁢nℛ𝑠𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑎𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑖𝑛superscript𝑠′12superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟subscript𝑖𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑠′ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟superscript𝑠′𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑚𝑖𝑛\mathcal{R}(s,t)=\left(1-\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\{a,b\}}p^{min}_{s^{\prime}}\right% )\times\frac{1}{2}\left(p_{s}^{t}+\frac{\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};% \mathcal{D}_{i_{s}}^{(t)})}{\sum_{s^{\prime}}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{% (t)};\mathcal{D}_{s^{\prime}}^{(t)})}\right)+p_{s}^{min}caligraphic_R ( italic_s , italic_t ) = ( 1 - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) × divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. −s𝑠-s- italic_s is the group other than s𝑠sitalic_s, while issubscript𝑖𝑠i_{s}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is found by first ranking all group-wise losses in ascending order and then selecting the (n+1−i)−t⁢h𝑛1𝑖𝑡ℎ(n+1-i)-th( italic_n + 1 - italic_i ) - italic_t italic_h largest loss if group s𝑠sitalic_s has the i−t⁢h𝑖𝑡ℎi-thitalic_i - italic_t italic_h largest loss. This retention dynamic is a direct generalization of the two-group case. Next, we show the retention of group ps(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑠p^{(t+1)}_{s}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time t+1𝑡1t+1italic_t + 1 is shown as Eqn. (13), resulting in the new data distribution D(t+1)superscript𝐷𝑡1D^{(t+1)}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

ps(t+1):=ℛ⁢(s,t)∑s′∈{a,b}ℛ⁢(s,t)assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑠ℛ𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑎𝑏ℛ𝑠𝑡p^{(t+1)}_{s}:=\frac{\mathcal{R}(s,t)}{\sum_{s^{\prime}\in\{a,b\}}\mathcal{R}(% s,t)}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG caligraphic_R ( italic_s , italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R ( italic_s , italic_t ) end_ARG (13)

We perform the mean estimation task for the whole data distribution with both RERM and Fair-RERM using the linear regression model. For Fair-RERM, we use RERM, Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM to perform 30303030 rounds of risk minimization where the loss is mean squared error (MSE), and name them as Fair-RERM-GLP (group-level penalty), Fair-RERM-SLP (sample-level penalty) and Fair-RERM-RW (reweighting). We first verify the convergence of performative loss of the above methods in Fig. 7 where all Fair-RERM methods have ρ=0.1𝜌0.1\rho=0.1italic_ρ = 0.1. The results demonstrate all methods successfully converge to the PS point.

Next, we verify the effectiveness of Fair-RERM by visualizing the dynamics of performative loss disparity between the groups while varying ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ in Fig. 8, where the higher ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ still results in lower loss disparity at the stable point, revealing that Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM are effective.

C.3 Performative Gaussian data classification.

We use a synthetic dataset consisting of 1000100010001000 samples from 2 demographic groups s∈{a,b}𝑠𝑎𝑏s\in\{a,b\}italic_s ∈ { italic_a , italic_b } with features X={X1,X2}𝑋subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2X=\{X_{1},X_{2}\}italic_X = { italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and labels Y∈{0,1}𝑌01Y\in\{0,1\}italic_Y ∈ { 0 , 1 }. For group a𝑎aitalic_a, Y=𝟙⁢{x1−0.5⁢x2≥0.5}𝑌1subscript𝑥10.5subscript𝑥20.5Y=\mathbbm{1}\{x_{1}-0.5x_{2}\geq 0.5\}italic_Y = blackboard_1 { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 0.5 italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.5 }. For group b𝑏bitalic_b, Y=𝟙⁢{0.5⁢x1+0.5⁢x2≥0.5}𝑌10.5subscript𝑥10.5subscript𝑥20.5Y=\mathbbm{1}\{0.5x_{1}+0.5x_{2}\geq 0.5\}italic_Y = blackboard_1 { 0.5 italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 0.5 italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.5 }. The initial group fraction and the retention mapping are the same as in the previous experiment. Using a logistic classification model for risk minimization, we first verify the convergence of performative loss in Fig. 9 and the effectiveness of Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM in Fig.13(a) and Fig. 13(b). All plots demonstrate the same trends as the previous experiment.

C.4 Gaussian Mean Estimation Using Group Loss Variance

In Example 4.2, we already prove that group loss variance as a fair penalty term violates the strong convexity assumption. In this section, we show its unconvergence while performing the Gaussian mean estimation task under the same setting mentioned in Section 6 when ρ=0.5𝜌0.5\rho=0.5italic_ρ = 0.5. The dynamics of ‖θt−θt−1‖normsubscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡1\|\theta_{t}-\theta_{t-1}\|∥ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ as well as performative loss are shown as follows. Fig. 11 shows the unconvergence, which is contradicted to Fig. 12(a) where we show the convergence of Fair-RERM.

C.5 K-delayed RERM on Credit Data

We examine the effectiveness of k-delayed RERM schema on Credit Data [23] which is the same dataset used by Brown et al. [5]. Specifically, we use k=3𝑘3k=3italic_k = 3 and ϵ=1italic-ϵ1\epsilon=1italic_ϵ = 1 to form equal-sized agent groups uniformly in the whole population to let each subgroup best respond with different speed (Example 1 in Brown et al. [5]). We also let the retention dynamic be k-delayed, adding additional challenges compared to the previous work. We examine ρ∈{0.3,0.7}𝜌0.30.7\rho\in\{0.3,0.7\}italic_ρ ∈ { 0.3 , 0.7 } while all other settings are the same as the Credit Data experiment in Section 6.

Then we first verify the convergence of performative loss in Fig. 9 and the effectiveness of k-delayed Fair-RERM-RW and Fair-RERM in Fig.13(a) and Fig. 13(b). All plots demonstrate the same trends as the previous experiment with RRM schema.

Appendix D Proofs for the Theoretical Results

D.1 Proof of Proposition 5.1

We will first present lemmas for this proposition.

Lemma D.1.

(First order optimality condition of convex functions [41]).

If f𝑓fitalic_f is convex and ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω is a closed convex set on which f𝑓fitalic_f is differentiable, then

x∗∈arg⁡minx∈Ω⁡f⁢(x),superscript𝑥subscript𝑥Ω𝑓𝑥x^{*}\in\arg\min_{x\in\Omega}f(x),italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ roman_Ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) , (14)

if and only if (y−x∗)⊤⁢∇g⁢(x∗)≥0superscript𝑦superscript𝑥top∇𝑔superscript𝑥0(y-x^{*})^{\top}\nabla g(x^{*})\geq 0( italic_y - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≥ 0 for all y∈Ω𝑦Ωy\in\Omegaitalic_y ∈ roman_Ω.

Lemma D.2.

(ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under fair penalty mechanisms is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex)

Under the conditions in Lemma 2.4, the loss aware objective ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eqn (7) and (8) are γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex.

Proof.

We will show this for the sample level fair penalty Eqn (8) first.

From conditions in Lemma 2.4, we know that ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex, and by definition ℓ≥0ℓ0\ell\geq 0roman_ℓ ≥ 0, we will show that ℓ2⁢(𝜽;Z)superscriptℓ2𝜽𝑍\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) is also convex in 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ. For simplicity of notation, we will derive for an arbitrary fixed Z𝑍Zitalic_Z and omit Z𝑍Zitalic_Z in the following derivation and use ℓ⁢(𝜽)ℓ𝜽\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta})roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ).

From the definition of convexity, we have ∀α∈(0,1),∀𝜽1,𝜽2∈Θformulae-sequencefor-all𝛼01for-allsubscript𝜽1subscript𝜽2Θ\forall\alpha\in(0,1),\forall\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\in\Theta∀ italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) , ∀ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ,

ℓ⁢((1−α)⁢𝜽1+α⁢𝜽2)≤(1−α)⁢ℓ⁢(𝜽1)+α⁢ℓ⁢(𝜽2).ℓ1𝛼subscript𝜽1𝛼subscript𝜽21𝛼ℓsubscript𝜽1𝛼ℓsubscript𝜽2\ell((1-\alpha)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}+\alpha\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})\leq(1-% \alpha)\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})+\alpha\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}).roman_ℓ ( ( 1 - italic_α ) bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ ( 1 - italic_α ) roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_α roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (15)

Squaring both sides in the above gives us

ℓ2⁢((1−α)⁢𝜽1+α⁢𝜽2)≤superscriptℓ21𝛼subscript𝜽1𝛼subscript𝜽2absent\displaystyle\ell^{2}((1-\alpha)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}+\alpha\boldsymbol{% \theta}_{2})\leqroman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( 1 - italic_α ) bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ (1−α)2⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽1)+α2⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽2)+2⁢α⁢(1−α)⁢ℓ⁢(𝜽1)⁢ℓ⁢(𝜽2)superscript1𝛼2superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽1superscript𝛼2superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽22𝛼1𝛼ℓsubscript𝜽1ℓsubscript𝜽2\displaystyle~{}(1-\alpha)^{2}\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})+\alpha^{2}\ell% ^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})+2\alpha(1-\alpha)\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})% \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})( 1 - italic_α ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + 2 italic_α ( 1 - italic_α ) roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (16)
=\displaystyle== (1−α)2⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽1)+α2⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽2)+2⁢α⁢(1−α)⁢ℓ⁢(𝜽1)⁢ℓ⁢(𝜽2)superscript1𝛼2superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽1superscript𝛼2superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽22𝛼1𝛼ℓsubscript𝜽1ℓsubscript𝜽2\displaystyle~{}(1-\alpha)^{2}\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})+\alpha^{2}\ell% ^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})+2\alpha(1-\alpha)\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})% \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})( 1 - italic_α ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + 2 italic_α ( 1 - italic_α ) roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
−(1−α)⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽1)−α⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽2)+(1−α)⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽1)+α⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽2)1𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽1𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽21𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽1𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽2\displaystyle~{}-(1-\alpha)\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})-\alpha\ell^{2}(% \boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})+(1-\alpha)\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})+\alpha% \ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})- ( 1 - italic_α ) roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_α roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( 1 - italic_α ) roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_α roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=\displaystyle== −α⁢(1−α)⁢[ℓ⁢(𝜽1)−ℓ2⁢(𝜽1)]2+(1−α)⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽1)+α⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽2)𝛼1𝛼superscriptdelimited-[]ℓsubscript𝜽1superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽121𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽1𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽2\displaystyle~{}-\alpha(1-\alpha)[\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})-\ell^{2}(% \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})]^{2}+(1-\alpha)\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})+% \alpha\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2})- italic_α ( 1 - italic_α ) [ roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_α ) roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_α roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
≤\displaystyle\leq≤ (1−α)⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽1)+α⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽2),1𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽1𝛼superscriptℓ2subscript𝜽2\displaystyle~{}(1-\alpha)\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1})+\alpha\ell^{2}(% \boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}),( 1 - italic_α ) roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_α roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

which shows the convexity of ℓ2superscriptℓ2\ell^{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Therefore, ℓ⁢(𝜽)+ρ⁢ℓ2⁢(𝜽)ℓ𝜽𝜌superscriptℓ2𝜽\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\rho\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ) + italic_ρ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ) is a sum of a γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex function and a convex function and thus is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex. Then since ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an affine combination of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex functions, it is also γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex.

For Eqn (7), since ℒssubscriptℒ𝑠\mathcal{L}_{s}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex for ∀sfor-all𝑠\forall s∀ italic_s, we can similarly show ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex. ∎

Lemma D.3.

(ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under fair penalty mechanisms is β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta}over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG-jointly smooth)

Under conditions in Lemma 2.4, the loss aware objective ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eqn (7) and (8) are β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta}over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG-jointly smooth, where β~=(2⁢ρ⁢ℓ¯+1)⁢β~𝛽2𝜌¯ℓ1𝛽\tilde{\beta}=(2\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\betaover~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG = ( 2 italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_β.

Proof.

Denote g:=ℓ2assign𝑔superscriptℓ2g:=\ell^{2}italic_g := roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then we have ∇𝜽g=2⁢ℓ⋅∇𝜽ℓsubscript∇𝜽𝑔⋅2ℓsubscript∇𝜽ℓ\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}g=2\ell\cdot\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g = 2 roman_ℓ ⋅ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ, and thus we have

‖∇𝜽g⁢(𝜽;Z)−∇𝜽g⁢(𝜽′;Z)‖2≤2⁢β⁢max⁡{ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z),ℓ⁢(𝜽′;Z)}⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2,subscriptnormsubscript∇𝜽𝑔𝜽𝑍subscript∇𝜽𝑔superscript𝜽′𝑍22𝛽ℓ𝜽𝑍ℓsuperscript𝜽′𝑍subscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\displaystyle~{}\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}g(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)-\nabla_% {\boldsymbol{\theta}}g(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime};Z)\|_{2}\leq 2\beta\max\{% \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z),\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime};Z)\}\|% \boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2},∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 2 italic_β roman_max { roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) , roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Z ) } ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (17)
‖∇𝜽g⁢(𝜽;Z)−∇𝜽g⁢(𝜽;Z′)‖2≤2⁢β⁢max⁡{ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z),ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z′)}⁢‖Z−Z′‖2,subscriptnormsubscript∇𝜽𝑔𝜽𝑍subscript∇𝜽𝑔𝜽superscript𝑍′22𝛽ℓ𝜽𝑍ℓ𝜽superscript𝑍′subscriptnorm𝑍superscript𝑍′2\displaystyle~{}\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}g(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)-\nabla_% {\boldsymbol{\theta}}g(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq 2\beta\max\{% \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z),\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z^{\prime})\}\|Z-Z^{% \prime}\|_{2},∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 2 italic_β roman_max { roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) , roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } ∥ italic_Z - italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

which implies (2⁢ρ⁢ℓ¯+1)⁢β2𝜌¯ℓ1𝛽(2\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\beta( 2 italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_β-joint smoothness of ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eqn (7) and (8). ∎

Lemma D.4.

For fair re-weighting mechanisms,

𝜽(t+1)=arg⁡min𝜽⁡ℒfair=arg⁡min𝜽⁢∑sps(t)⁢(1+ρ⁢ℒs⁢(𝜽(t));𝒟s(t−1))⁢ℒs⁢(𝜽);𝒟s(t),formulae-sequencesuperscript𝜽𝑡1subscript𝜽subscriptℒfairsubscript𝜽subscript𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑡1𝜌subscriptℒ𝑠superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡1𝑠subscriptℒ𝑠𝜽subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑠\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf% {fair}}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\sum_{s}p_{s}^{(t)}(1+\rho\mathcal{L}_{s% }(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)});\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}_{s})\mathcal{L}_{s}(% \boldsymbol{\theta});\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{s},bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_ρ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ) ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (18)

where ∑sps(t)(1+ρℒs(𝛉(t);𝒟s(t−1))ℒs(𝛉;𝒟s(t))\sum_{s}p_{s}^{(t)}(1+\rho\mathcal{L}_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D% }^{(t-1)}_{s})\mathcal{L}_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{s})∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_ρ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex and (1+ρ⁢ℓ¯)1𝜌¯ℓ(1+\rho\overline{\ell})( 1 + italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG )-jointly smooth.

Proof.

At a high level, (1+ρ⁢ℒs⁢(𝜽(t));𝒟s(t−1))1𝜌subscriptℒ𝑠superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡1𝑠(1+\rho\mathcal{L}_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)});\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}_{s})( 1 + italic_ρ caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) acts like a scalar that may scale the strong convexity and joint smoothness coefficient.

Since ℒs(𝜽(t));𝒟s(t−1))≥0\mathcal{L}_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)});\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}_{s})\geq 0caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥ 0, we know the γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strong convexity part holds.

Similarly, since ℒs(𝜽(t));𝒟s(t−1))≤ℓ¯\mathcal{L}_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)});\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}_{s})\leq% \overline{\ell}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG, we know the (1+ρ⁢ℓ¯)1𝜌¯ℓ(1+\rho\overline{\ell})( 1 + italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG )-joint smoothness holds. ∎

This lemma shows that we can treat ℒs⁢(𝜽(t);𝒟s(t−1))⁢ℒs⁢(𝜽;𝒟s(t))subscriptℒ𝑠superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡1𝑠subscriptℒ𝑠𝜽subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑠\mathcal{L}_{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)};\mathcal{D}^{(t-1)}_{s})\mathcal{L}_% {s}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{s})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as the fair objective in fair er-weighting mechanisms, where this objective has very similar properties as the fair objectives using the fair penalty mechanism.

Based on the above lemmas, we present a result that bounds the fair-aware loss minimization solution distance from two different input distributions, where [4] and [5] derived similar bounds in the PP cases without fairness penalties.

Lemma D.5.

(Bounding the fair objective minimizers)

Given fair-aware loss function ℒfairsubscriptℒfair\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-strongly convex and β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta}over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG-jointly smooth. Then for two distributions 𝒟,𝒟~∈△⁢(𝒵)𝒟~𝒟△𝒵\mathcal{D},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}\in\triangle(\mathcal{Z})caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ∈ △ ( caligraphic_Z ), denote

𝜽fair∗=G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair):=arg⁡min𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟),𝜽~fair∗=G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair):=arg⁡min𝜽⁡ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟~),formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜽fair𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfairassignsubscript𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟superscriptsubscript~𝜽fair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfairassignsubscript𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽~𝒟\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\textsf{fair}}^{*}=G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{% fair}}):=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol% {\theta};\mathcal{D}),~{}~{}~{}\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{\textsf{fair}}^{*}% =G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}):=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{% \theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\tilde{\mathcal{D}}),bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) , over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) , (19)

we have

‖𝜽fair∗−𝜽~fair∗‖2≤β~γ⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟~).subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜽fairsuperscriptsubscript~𝜽fair2~𝛽𝛾subscript𝒲1𝒟~𝒟\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\textsf{fair}}^{*}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{\textsf% {fair}}^{*}\|_{2}\leq\frac{\tilde{\beta}}{\gamma}\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},% \tilde{\mathcal{D}}).∥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) . (20)
Proof.

Using the strong convexity property and the fact that G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfairG(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the unique minimizer of ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟)subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ), we can derive that

−γ⁢‖G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair)‖22≥(G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair))⊤⁢∇𝜽ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟).𝛾superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfair22superscript𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfairtopsubscript∇𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟-\gamma\|G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};% \mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})\|_{2}^{2}\geq(G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{% fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}))^{\top}\nabla_{% \boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D% }).- italic_γ ∥ italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ ( italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) . (21)

Then for Eqn (8), we observe that

(G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair))⊤⁢∇𝜽ℓ⁢(𝜽;Z)superscript𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfairtopsubscript∇𝜽ℓ𝜽𝑍(G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};\mathcal{L}_% {\textsf{fair}}))^{\top}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta};Z)( italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) (22)

is ‖G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair)‖2⁢βsubscriptnorm𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfair2𝛽\|G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};\mathcal{L}% _{\textsf{fair}})\|_{2}\beta∥ italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β-Lipschitz in Z𝑍Zitalic_Z, and

(G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair))⊤⁢∇𝜽ℓ2⁢(𝜽;Z)superscript𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfairtopsubscript∇𝜽superscriptℓ2𝜽𝑍(G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};\mathcal{L}_% {\textsf{fair}}))^{\top}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\ell^{2}(\boldsymbol{% \theta};Z)( italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; italic_Z ) (23)

is 2⁢ℓ¯⁢‖G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair)‖2⁢β2¯ℓsubscriptnorm𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfair2𝛽2\overline{\ell}\|G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal% {D}};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})\|_{2}\beta2 over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG ∥ italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β-Lipschitz in Z𝑍Zitalic_Z, which follows from applying the Cauchy Schwartz inequality and the fact that ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is β𝛽\betaitalic_β-jointly smooth.

Then we can derive that

(G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair))⊤⁢∇𝜽ℒfair⁢(𝜽;𝒟)≥−(2⁢ρ⁢ℓ¯+1)⁢β⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟~),superscript𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfairtopsubscript∇𝜽subscriptℒfair𝜽𝒟2𝜌¯ℓ1𝛽subscript𝒲1𝒟~𝒟(G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};\mathcal{L}_% {\textsf{fair}}))^{\top}\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}% }(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})\geq-(2\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\beta\mathcal{W% }_{1}(\mathcal{D},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}),( italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) ≥ - ( 2 italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_β caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) , (24)

and thus

−γ⁢‖G⁢(𝒟;ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟~;ℒfair)‖22≥−(2⁢ρ⁢ℓ¯+1)⁢β⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟~),𝛾superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐺𝒟subscriptℒfair𝐺~𝒟subscriptℒfair222𝜌¯ℓ1𝛽subscript𝒲1𝒟~𝒟-\gamma\|G(\mathcal{D};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})-G(\tilde{\mathcal{D}};% \mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})\|_{2}^{2}\geq-(2\rho\overline{\ell}+1)\beta% \mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}),- italic_γ ∥ italic_G ( caligraphic_D ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ - ( 2 italic_ρ over¯ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG + 1 ) italic_β caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , over~ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG ) , (25)

we get the proof for Eqn (8), and we can similarly prove this for Eqn (7) and (9). ∎

Lemma D.6.

(Bounding the fixed point distribution distance using parameter distance [5])

Suppose the transition mapping T𝑇Titalic_T is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-jointly sensitive with ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1)italic_ϵ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), then for 𝛉1,𝛉2subscript𝛉1subscript𝛉2\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and their corresponding fixed point distributions 𝒟1,𝒟2subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it holds that

𝒲1⁢(𝒟1,𝒟2)≤ϵ1−ϵ⁢‖𝜽1−𝜽2‖2subscript𝒲1subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2italic-ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptnormsubscript𝜽1subscript𝜽22\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2})\leq\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon% }\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\|_{2}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (26)

Proposition 5.1. (Unique Fair-PS solution) Under Conditions in Lemma 2.4, if ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1, then for a given combination of (1) initial distribution 𝒟(0)superscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}^{(0)}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and (2) fair mechanism with strength ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, there is a unique Fair-PS solution.

Proof.

We define the fixed point transition mapping as

TFP⁢(𝜽;𝒟):=𝒟𝜽=TFP⁢(𝜽)assignsuperscriptTFP𝜽𝒟subscript𝒟𝜽superscriptTFP𝜽\text{T}^{\text{FP}}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}):=\mathcal{D}_{% \boldsymbol{\theta}}=\text{T}^{\text{FP}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT FP end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) := caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT FP end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ) (27)

the mapping returning the model’s fixed point distribution.

Then using the results in Lemma D.2, D.3, D.5, D.4, D.6, we can see that

𝜽(t+1)=G⁢(TFP⁢(𝜽(t));ℒfair)superscript𝜽𝑡1𝐺superscriptTFPsuperscript𝜽𝑡subscriptℒfair\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}=G(\text{T}^{\text{FP}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)});% \mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_G ( T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT FP end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (28)

is a contraction mapping when conditions in Lemma 2.4 hold since ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1. Therefore, using the Banach fixed-point theorem, we know that there is a unique Fair-PS pair. ∎

D.2 Proof of Theorem 5.2

In this part, we provide the convergence of the class of Fair-RRM algorithms in Algorithm 1.

Lemma D.7.

([5]) Under conditions in Lemma 2.4, given a decision model with parameter 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ, denote the parameter returned by Delayed Deployment Scheme as 𝒟^θ:=TD⁢L⁢(𝛉;𝒟)assignsubscript^𝒟𝜃superscriptT𝐷𝐿𝛉𝒟\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\theta}:=\text{T}^{DL}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D})over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) and the fixed point distribution of 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ as 𝒟𝛉subscript𝒟𝛉\mathcal{D}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then

𝒲1⁢(𝒟^𝜽,𝒟𝜽)≤ϵ1−ϵ⁢δsubscript𝒲1subscript^𝒟𝜽subscript𝒟𝜽italic-ϵ1italic-ϵ𝛿\mathcal{W}_{1}(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}},\mathcal{D}_{% \boldsymbol{\theta}})\leq\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon}\deltacaligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG italic_δ (29)
Proof.
111Due to different notations, we present the proof in [5] to help the readers.

For a fixed 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}bold_italic_θ and ϵ<1italic-ϵ1\epsilon<1italic_ϵ < 1, the map T⁢(𝜽;⋅)T𝜽⋅\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\cdot)T ( bold_italic_θ ; ⋅ ) is contracting with Lipschitz coefficient ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ and has a unique fixed point 𝒟𝜽subscript𝒟𝜽\mathcal{D}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that 𝒟^𝜽=T⌈r⌉+1subscript^𝒟𝜽superscriptT𝑟1\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\text{T}^{\lceil r\rceil+1}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⌈ italic_r ⌉ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, denote 𝒟1=T⁢(𝜽;𝒟0)superscript𝒟1𝑇𝜽superscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}^{1}=T(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}^{0})caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), then

𝒲1⁢(𝒟^𝜽,𝒟𝜽)≤ϵ⌈r⌉1−ϵ⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟0,𝒟1),subscript𝒲1subscript^𝒟𝜽subscript𝒟𝜽superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟1italic-ϵsubscript𝒲1superscript𝒟0superscript𝒟1\mathcal{W}_{1}(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}},\mathcal{D}_{% \boldsymbol{\theta}})\leq\frac{\epsilon^{\lceil r\rceil}}{1-\epsilon}\mathcal{% W}_{1}(\mathcal{D}^{0},\mathcal{D}^{1}),caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⌈ italic_r ⌉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (30)

then since r=log−1⁡(1ϵ)⁢log⁡(𝒲1⁢(𝒟0,𝒟1)δ)𝑟superscript11italic-ϵsubscript𝒲1superscript𝒟0superscript𝒟1𝛿r=\log^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)\log\left(\frac{\mathcal{W}_{1}(% \mathcal{D}^{0},\mathcal{D}^{1})}{\delta}\right)italic_r = roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ), we have ϵ⌈r⌉<ϵr=δ𝒲1⁢(𝒟0,𝒟1)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝛿subscript𝒲1superscript𝒟0superscript𝒟1\epsilon^{\lceil r\rceil}<\epsilon^{r}=\frac{\delta}{\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{% D}^{0},\mathcal{D}^{1})}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⌈ italic_r ⌉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG, which completes the proof. ∎

Theorem 5.2. (Fair-RRM Convergence) Under conditions in Lemma 2.4:

(i) If ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1, Algorithm 1 under the Conventional Schema converges to the Fair-PS pair at a linear rate.

(ii) If ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1−ϵitalic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1italic-ϵ\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1-\epsilonitalic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1 - italic_ϵ, Algorithm 1 under the k𝑘kitalic_k-Delayed Schema converges to the Fair-PS pair at a linear rate for any k𝑘kitalic_k.

(iii) If ϵ⁢(1+β~/γ)<1italic-ϵ1~𝛽𝛾1\epsilon(1+\tilde{\beta}/\gamma)<1italic_ϵ ( 1 + over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG / italic_γ ) < 1, Algorithm 1 under the Conventional Schema converges to a δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ neighborhood of the Fair-PS pair in O⁢(log2⁡1δ)𝑂superscript21𝛿O(\log^{2}\frac{1}{\delta})italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) steps.

proof of (i).

We will define a distance metric

dpair⁢((𝜽1,𝒟1),(𝜽2,𝒟2)):=𝒲1⁢(𝒟1,𝒟2)+‖𝜽1−𝜽2‖2.assignsubscript𝑑pairsubscript𝜽1subscript𝒟1subscript𝜽2subscript𝒟2subscript𝒲1subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2subscriptnormsubscript𝜽1subscript𝜽22d_{\text{pair}}((\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{1}),(\boldsymbol{\theta}% _{2},\mathcal{D}_{2})):=\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2})+\|% \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\|_{2}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) := caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ∥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (31)

Denote the Fair-RRM mapping as

Ffair⁢(𝜽,𝒟):=(Gfair⁢(𝜽,𝒟),T⁢(𝜽;𝒟))assignsubscript𝐹fair𝜽𝒟subscript𝐺fair𝜽𝒟T𝜽𝒟F_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathcal{D}):=(G_{\textsf{fair}}(% \boldsymbol{\theta},\mathcal{D}),\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}))italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , caligraphic_D ) := ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) ) (32)

where Gfair⁢(𝜽,𝒟):=G⁢(T⁢(𝜽;𝒟);ℒfair)assignsubscript𝐺fair𝜽𝒟𝐺T𝜽𝒟subscriptℒfairG_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathcal{D}):=G(\text{T}(\boldsymbol{% \theta};\mathcal{D});\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , caligraphic_D ) := italic_G ( T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then

dpair⁢(Ffair⁢(𝜽,𝒟),Ffair⁢(𝜽′,𝒟′))=𝒲1⁢(T⁢(𝜽;𝒟),T⁢(𝜽′;𝒟′))+‖Gfair⁢(𝜽,𝒟)−Gfair⁢(𝜽′,𝒟′)‖2.subscript𝑑pairsubscript𝐹fair𝜽𝒟subscript𝐹fairsuperscript𝜽′superscript𝒟′subscript𝒲1T𝜽𝒟Tsuperscript𝜽′superscript𝒟′subscriptnormsubscript𝐺fair𝜽𝒟subscript𝐺fairsuperscript𝜽′superscript𝒟′2d_{\text{pair}}(F_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathcal{D}),F_{\textsf{% fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))=\mathcal{W}_{1}(% \text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}),\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime% };\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))+\|G_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathcal{D})-% G_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\|_{2}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , caligraphic_D ) , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + ∥ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , caligraphic_D ) - italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (33)

The ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-jointly sensitivity of the transition map T yields

𝒲1⁢(T⁢(𝜽;𝒟),T⁢(𝜽′;𝒟′))≤ϵ⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟′)+ϵ⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2,subscript𝒲1T𝜽𝒟Tsuperscript𝜽′superscript𝒟′italic-ϵsubscript𝒲1𝒟superscript𝒟′italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\mathcal{W}_{1}(\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}),\text{T}(\boldsymbol% {\theta}^{\prime};\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D% },\mathcal{D}^{\prime})+\epsilon\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{% \prime}\|_{2},caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ≤ italic_ϵ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_ϵ ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (34)

and using Lemma D.5, we get

‖Gfair⁢(𝜽,𝒟)−Gfair⁢(𝜽′,𝒟′)‖2≤β~γ⁢𝒲1⁢(T⁢(𝜽;𝒟),T⁢(𝜽′;𝒟′))≤ϵ⁢β~γ⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟′)+ϵ⁢β~γ⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2.subscriptnormsubscript𝐺fair𝜽𝒟subscript𝐺fairsuperscript𝜽′superscript𝒟′2~𝛽𝛾subscript𝒲1T𝜽𝒟Tsuperscript𝜽′superscript𝒟′italic-ϵ~𝛽𝛾subscript𝒲1𝒟superscript𝒟′italic-ϵ~𝛽𝛾subscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\|G_{\textsf{fair}}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathcal{D})-G_{\textsf{fair}}(% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq\frac{\tilde{\beta% }}{\gamma}\mathcal{W}_{1}(\text{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\mathcal{D}),\text{T}(% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime};\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon\frac{\tilde{% \beta}}{\gamma}\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})+\epsilon\frac% {\tilde{\beta}}{\gamma}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2}.∥ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , caligraphic_D ) - italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( T ( bold_italic_θ ; caligraphic_D ) , T ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ≤ italic_ϵ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_ϵ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (35)

Combining the above two equations, we get that under conditions in Lemma 2.4, the Fair-RRM mapping is a contraction mapping that has a unique fixed point, where the fixed point satisfies the criteria of being the PS solution.

The proof of this part referenced [5] Theorem 4. ∎

proof of (ii).

We can derive the sensitivity of Tk⁢(𝒟,𝜽)superscript𝑇𝑘𝒟𝜽T^{k}(\mathcal{D},\boldsymbol{\theta})italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , bold_italic_θ ) as follows

𝒲1⁢(Tk⁢(𝒟,𝜽),Tk⁢(𝒟′,𝜽′))subscript𝒲1superscript𝑇𝑘𝒟𝜽superscript𝑇𝑘superscript𝒟′superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\mathcal{W}_{1}(T^{k}(\mathcal{D},\boldsymbol{\theta}),T^{k}(% \mathcal{D}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}))caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , bold_italic_θ ) , italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) (36)
≤\displaystyle\leq≤ ϵ⁢𝒲1⁢(Tk−1⁢(𝒟,𝜽),Tk−1⁢(𝒟′,𝜽′))+ϵ⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2italic-ϵsubscript𝒲1superscript𝑇𝑘1𝒟𝜽superscript𝑇𝑘1superscript𝒟′superscript𝜽′italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\displaystyle\epsilon\mathcal{W}_{1}(T^{k-1}(\mathcal{D},\boldsymbol{\theta}),% T^{k-1}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}))+\epsilon\|% \boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2}italic_ϵ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , bold_italic_θ ) , italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + italic_ϵ ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
≤\displaystyle\leq≤ ϵ2⁢𝒲1⁢(Tk−2⁢(𝒟,𝜽),Tk−2⁢(𝒟′,𝜽′))+(ϵ+ϵ2)⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2superscriptitalic-ϵ2subscript𝒲1superscript𝑇𝑘2𝒟𝜽superscript𝑇𝑘2superscript𝒟′superscript𝜽′italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2subscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\displaystyle\epsilon^{2}\mathcal{W}_{1}(T^{k-2}(\mathcal{D},\boldsymbol{% \theta}),T^{k-2}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}))+(\epsilon% +\epsilon^{2})\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|_{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , bold_italic_θ ) , italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + ( italic_ϵ + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
≤\displaystyle\leq≤ ……\displaystyle\dots…
<\displaystyle<< ϵk⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟′)+ϵ1−ϵ⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘subscript𝒲1𝒟superscript𝒟′italic-ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\displaystyle\epsilon^{k}\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})+% \frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}% \|_{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
<\displaystyle<< ϵ1−ϵ⁢𝒲1⁢(𝒟,𝒟′)+ϵ1−ϵ⁢‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2italic-ϵ1italic-ϵsubscript𝒲1𝒟superscript𝒟′italic-ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\displaystyle\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon}\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D% }^{\prime})+\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{% \theta}^{\prime}\|_{2}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_θ - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

So Tk⁢(𝒟,𝜽)superscript𝑇𝑘𝒟𝜽T^{k}(\mathcal{D},\boldsymbol{\theta})italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , bold_italic_θ ) is (ϵ1−ϵ)italic-ϵ1italic-ϵ(\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon})( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG )-jointly sensitive.

Using the proof of contraction mapping in part (i), we complete the proof of part (ii). ∎

proof of (iii).

Similar to the above, we denote the parameter returned by the Delayed Deployment Scheme as 𝒟^𝜽=TD⁢L⁢(𝜽;⋅)subscript^𝒟𝜽superscriptT𝐷𝐿𝜽⋅\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\text{T}^{DL}(\boldsymbol{\theta};\cdot)over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ; ⋅ ). We have 𝜽(t+1)=G⁢(𝒟^𝜽(t);ℒfair)superscript𝜽𝑡1𝐺subscript^𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptℒfair\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}=G(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}};% \mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_G ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Recall that 𝜽fairPS=G⁢(𝒟fairPS;ℒfair)subscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfair𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairsubscriptℒfair\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}=G(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{% \textsf{fair}};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_G ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then Lemma D.5 indicates that

‖𝜽(t+1)−𝜽fairPS‖2=‖G⁢(𝒟^𝜽(t);ℒfair)−G⁢(𝒟fairPS;ℒfair)‖2≤β~γ⋅𝒲1⁢(𝒟^𝜽(t),𝒟fairPS).subscriptnormsuperscript𝜽𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfair2subscriptnorm𝐺subscript^𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptℒfair𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairsubscriptℒfair2⋅~𝛽𝛾subscript𝒲1subscript^𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair\|\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}% \|_{2}=\|G(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{% fair}})-G(\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}};\mathcal{L}_{\textsf{fair}})% \|_{2}\leq\frac{\tilde{\beta}}{\gamma}\cdot\mathcal{W}_{1}(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}).∥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∥ italic_G ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_G ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG ⋅ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (37)

Using the triangle inequality, we have

𝒲1⁢(𝒟^𝜽,𝒟fairPS)≤𝒲1⁢(𝒟^𝜽,𝒟𝜽(t))+𝒲1⁢(𝒟𝜽(t),𝒟fairPS),subscript𝒲1subscript^𝒟𝜽subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairsubscript𝒲1subscript^𝒟𝜽subscript𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝒲1subscript𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfair\mathcal{W}_{1}(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}% }_{\textsf{fair}})\leq\mathcal{W}_{1}(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}},% \mathcal{D}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}})+\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D}_{% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}),caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (38)

where 𝒟𝜽(t)subscript𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡\mathcal{D}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the fixed point distribution of 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We can use Lemma D.7 to get 𝒲1⁢(𝒟^𝜽,𝒟𝜽(t))≤ϵ⁢δ1−ϵsubscript𝒲1subscript^𝒟𝜽subscript𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡italic-ϵ𝛿1italic-ϵ\mathcal{W}_{1}(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}},\mathcal{D}_{% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}})\leq\frac{\epsilon\delta}{1-\epsilon}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG and use Lemma D.6 and the sensitivity definition to get 𝒲1⁢(𝒟𝜽(t),𝒟fairPS)≤ϵ1−ϵ⁢‖𝜽(t)−𝜽fairPS‖2subscript𝒲1subscript𝒟superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟PSfairitalic-ϵ1italic-ϵsubscriptnormsuperscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜽PSfair2\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}},\mathcal{D}^{\text{PS}% }_{\textsf{fair}})\leq\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-% \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\text{PS}}_{\textsf{fair}}\|_{2}caligraphic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_ϵ end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT PS end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fair end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Therefore,
